pages.title: Controlled Intubation Checklist
content: Hemodynamics Optimized - Hypotension + Metabolic Acidosis Addressed
Patient Positioned - Ear to Sternal Notch, Head Up, Occiput Elevated
Cardiac Monitor - NIBP (q 2 minutes), SpO2, EtCO2
Preoxygenation - Mask O2 > 15 LPM + Nasal O2 15 LPM/NPPV/BVM + PEEP
Drug/Doses - Inducation, Paralysis, Post ETI Analgosedation
MILS Assistant Briefed - Neck Stabilized, Collar Open
Brief 30 Second Drills - Additional ELM / Extra Head Lift / Operator Position / Blade Change / Blade Deep
Standardized Airway Bag Open and Reviewed
ETT/SGA Secured, Depth Confirmed, Cuff Pressure 20-30 cmH20
CMAC Record Button Off if Not Already Done
Ventilator - Settings, Circuit, In-Line Suction, Filter, ETCO2
Supplies - Oxygen, Drugs, Power, Airway Bag Packed Up

pages.title: Adult - Supraglottic Airway
pages.indications:
• Weight > 2 kg
• Need for ventilatory assistance OR airway control AND
• Other airway management is inadequate OR ineffective OR unsuccessful
pages.contraindications:
• Intact gag reflex
• Caustic ingestion
• Active vomiting
pages.clinical:
• Supraglottic airway should be the initial airway strategy in out of hospital cardiac arrest unless endotracheal intubation is deemed more appropriate by the paramedic
• Endotracheal intubation is usually preferred for secure airway management in the non cardiac arrest patient. In this setting, SGA is considered a rescue device if BLS airway/ventilation and other advanced airway maneuvers have been unsuccessful
• Confirm placement (EtCO2 waveform + chest rise)

drug_cards.title: Supraglottic Airway
dose_route:
<center>Insert Airway
MAX 2 attempts

If two (2) attempts at supraglottic airway have failed, then revert to BVM and oral / nasal pharyngeal airway management</center>

pages.title: Adult - Pre-Intubation and Intubation Medications
pages.indications: • Intubation attempts
pages.contraindications:
• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication
• See specific contraindications for medications below
pages.treatment: It is expected that in virtually ALL circumstances the Paramedic will patch to the TMP prior to performing a Rapid Sequence Intubation or Sedation Facilitated Intubation (SFI) (see mandatory patch points below) but it is recognized that there may be rare circumstances in which a patient requires immediate intubation with sedation/dissociation and a timely patch cannot be completed. In this circumstance utilize the medication guidelines below to perform the intubation and patch as soon as possible.
pages.clinical:
<tab1>• RSI intubation falls under the CCP and PCCP/PCCN scope
• If patient requires recurrent doses of phenylephrine to maintain adequate MAP consult the TMP</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Lidocaine (Xylocaine) Spray
dose_route:
<center>10 mg/spray onto the pharynx, hypopharynx
MAX cumulative dose of 5 mg/kg or 400 mg</center>
drug_cards.notes: *Consider Lidocaine for oro-tracheal facilitated and awake intubations

drug_cards.section: For Sedation Choose only one sedative agent +/- analgesic KETAMINE IS THE PREFERRED AGENT IN THE MAJORITY OF PATIENTS
drug_cards.title: Ketamine
Midazolam
dose_route:
<center>0.1 mg/kg IV (to a MAX of 8 mg
contraindicated if MAP < 80
<b>Titrating doses (up to the above doses) in potentially difficult airway for awake intubation (1-2 mg every 3-5 minutes)</center>

drug_cards.title: Propofol
drug_cards.notes:
CAUTION:
• Respiratory apnea and hypotension may occur with rapid induction 
• Avoid in elderly or hypovolemia or poor cardiovascular reserve
• Phenylephrine should be used to support BP if hypotension occurs
• Should be avoided in hypotension with head injury

drug_cards.title: Fentanyl (Sublimaze)
drug_cards.notes: Avoid or reduced titrated dosage (25-50 microgram IV every 3-5 minutes) if elderly, decreased level of consciousness, or maximally sympathetically stimulated and poor cardiovascular reserve

drug_cards.section: For Paralysis ROCURONIUM IS THE PREFERRED PARALYTIC IN THE MAJORITY OF PATIENTS
drug_cards.title: Rocuronium (Zemuron)
Succinylcholine (Anectine)
drug_cards.notes:
Contraindicated With:
<tab1>• Malignant hyperthermia
• Hyperkalemia (known or concern)
• Myopathies/Muscular dystrophies
• Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis, Multiple Sclerosis
• Guillain-Barre Syndrome, botulism
• Burns ≥ 2nd degree over 10% BSA > 24 hours until healed
• Stroke with hemiparesis, spinal cord injury > 72 hours until 6 months post injury
• Severe intra-abdominal sepsis > 72 hours until resolution</tab1>

drug_cards.section: Treatment of Hypotension associated with Sedation
drug_cards.title: Phenylephrine (Neosynephrine)
dose_route: MAP < 65 MAP < 80 (high ICP, ischemic stroke or spinal cord injury) 100 micrograms IV/IO q 3 minutes prn MAX 3 doses (300 micrograms)

pages.title: Adult - Emergency Tracheostomy Tube Reinsertion
pages.indications:
<tab1>• Patient with existing tracheostomy where the inner and/or outer cannula(s) have been removed from the airway;
AND
• Respiratory distress
AND
• Inability to adequately ventilate</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Inability to landmark or visualize</tab1>
pages.clinical:
<tab1>• Risk is much higher on reinsertion of tube into tracheostomy, cricothyrotomy, or laryngectomy site when less than 7 days since creation. Reinsertion may create a false passage with subcutaneous emphysema and fatal hypoxia due to inability to secure the airway
• Risk is higher if tube placed for airway obstruction, difficult airway, or laryngectomy (due to inability to manage airway from above)
• At minimum always bring a spare inner cannula which is size and type (disposable or reusable) specific for patient’s tracheostomy tube
• At minimum, a complete spare tracheostomy tube one size smaller should be available during transport
• Ensure tracheostomy ties are snug (i.e. can only fit two fingers between the tie and the patient’s neck) prior to transport
• A reinsertion attempt is defined as the insertion of the cannula into the tracheostomy replacing the inner and/or outer cannula with a new one is preferred over cleaning and reusing an existing one
NOTE: Please refer to the matrix below on the next page.</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Consider Emergency Tracheostomy Tube Reinsertion
dose_route:
<center>The Maximum number of attempts is 2

If unable to replace, initiate BVM from above
Requires occlusion of the stoma with palm of hand, tegaderm or occlusive dressing</center>

<center>If cannot re-insert existing tracheostomy tube or re-insert an alternate tracheostomy tube
Place cuffed ETT 6.0 or smaller over bougie through patient stoma site
Confirm with ETC02 and clinical indicators</center>

pages.title: Adult - Bronchoconstriction
pages.indications:
<tab1>• Respiratory distress AND
• Suspected bronchoconstriction</tab1>
pages.contraindications:
<tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication
• Allergy to peanuts (i.e. Ipratropium Bromide (Atrovent))</tab1>
pages.clinical:
<tab1>• MDI delivery systems require 45 seconds to “re-charge” between doses. Not waiting the recommended length of time between doses will result in significantly decreased amounts of medication being delivered/activation
• In the event of a respiratory outbreak as identified by originating facility / Ornge, the MDI must be used instead of nebulization
• Side effects of Magnesium Sulfate include hypotension; monitor BP closely</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Salbutamol (Ventolin) MDI (100 microgram/puff)
dose_route:
<center>8 puffs
(45 seconds between each administration)
may repeat x 3 q 5-15 minutes prn</center>

drug_cards.title: Salbutamol (Ventolin) Solution Via Nebulized Aerosol (2.5 mg/2.5 mL)
drug_cards.notes: *Total volume of Salbutamol and Normal Saline should be 3 mL

drug_cards.title: Ipratropium Bromide (Atrovent) MDI (20 microgram/puff)
dose_route:
<center>5 puffs
(45 seconds between each administration)
may repeat x 3 every 15 minutes prn
MAX 3 doses</center>

drug_cards.title: Ipratropium Bromide (Atrovent) Solution< Via Nebulized Aerosol (250 mg/mL)
dose_route:
<center>500 micrograms q 15 minutes x 3 prn
MAX 3 doses</center>
drug_cards.notes: *Total volume of Ipratropium Bromide (Atrovent) and Normal Saline should be 3 mL

drug_cards.title: EPINEPHrine (Adrenalin)
drug_cards.notes: Use with caution when history of coronary artery disease or stroke

drug_cards.title: Magnesium Sulfate
dose_route:
<center>2 g (4 mL)/100 mL
Administer over 15 minutes</center>

pages.title: Adult - Tension Pneumothorax
pages.indications: • Severe respiratory distress in the setting of chest trauma with hemodynamic compromise AND/OR • Traumatic VSAs AND/OR • Severe hemodynamic compromise during positive pressure ventilation particularly in trauma or asthma or COPD patients AND/OR • Chest trauma, Severe Asthma or COPD, hemodynamic compromise and one or more of the following: ◦ Decreased/absent breath sounds on affected side ◦ Cyanosis ◦ JVD ◦ Hyper resonance on affected side ◦ Tracheal shift (late sign)
pages.contraindications: • Not applicable
pages.clinical:
<tab1>• The patient must be seen as soon as possible at an appropriate facility for the insertion of chest tube(s)
• Consider differential diagnosis:
</tab1><tab2>◦ Main stem intubation
◦ Pleural effusion
◦ Hemothorax
◦ Consolidated pneumonia
◦ Auto PEEP
◦ Dynamic hyperinflation</tab2>

dose_route: Consider differential diagnosis and decompress if high probability of tension pneumothorax

pages.title: Adult - Maintenance of Chest Tubes
pages.indications: • Initiated by sending facility
pages.contraindications: • Not applicable
pages.clinical:
<tab1>• A Heimlich flutter valve may be adequate if no drainage system has been implemented
• Suction beyond -20 cm H2O requires patch authorization prior to transport</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Maintain chest drainage systems during call to keep the drainage system clear
dose_route: If the patient’s chest tube was maintained by suction at the sending facility, the Paramedic may maintain suction to no greater than -20 cm H2O
If the patient’s chest tube was maintained by gravity drainage, the Paramedic may maintain by gravity drainage to underwater seal or to suction as per patient presentation

pages.title: Adult - Initiating or Maintaining Mechanical Ventilation
pages.indications:
<tab1>• Need for mechanical ventilation
• Hypoxemic respiratory failure
• Hypercapnic respiratory failure
• Mixed hypoxemic hypercapnic respiratory failure
• ETI airway management for transport</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Not applicable</tab1>
pages.treatment: All mechanically ventilated patients should be managed using standard settings with 'goal-directed ventilation orders' • CCPs may initiate and maintain mechanical ventilation without patching for patients who are intubated/ventilated for airway protection/patency; or patients with mild-to-moderate respiratory failure that do not require high levels of mechanical ventilation support • CCPs are not required to patch if they can achieve the following: o Ventilation goals: • SpO2 94-98% (88-92% if known CO2 retainer and this is target SpO2 at sending facility) • ETCO2 35-45 (or 33-38 if increased ICP) o Using mechanical ventilation settings within the following safety parameters: • Vt 6-8 ml/kg IBW (target Vt must be calculated and documented in ePCR) • Frequency of 10-20 breaths per minute • FiO2 0.6 or less • PEEP range 5-10 • Peak and plateau pressure less than or equal to 30 cm H20 • I:E ratio range 1:1.5-3.0 • Contraindications to CCP initiation and maintenance of mechanical ventilation without patch include: o Sending facility ventilation settings outside of safety parameters above • Exception: If FiO2 at sending facility higher than 0.6, CCP medics may attempt brief weaning trial prior to departing sending facility and if able to wean to 0.6 and achieve oxygen saturation 94-98% patch not required o Inability to maintain mechanical ventilation goals without exceeding safety parameters above o Use of oxygenation adjuncts at sending facility such as inhaled heliox, nitric oxide, inhaled Flolan or prone positioning o Serum bicarbonate (from ABG/VBG/electrolytes) < 15 or > 35 (need to clarify pH/ETCO2 target with TMP) • CCPs may use AC Pressure Control ventilation or Volume Control ventilation to achieve mechanical ventilation goals for patients requiring controlled ventilation with guaranteed rate/minute ventilation; for patients spontaneously breathing consider Pressure Support ventilation* (potential benefit of decreased need for sedation) • ACP(f)s MUST patch prior to initiating or maintaining ventilation in ALL patients. • All paramedics should plan to ventilate patients utilizing the treatment guidelines below. • When mechanical ventilation is initiated, all settings and patient’s response to treatment must be documented on the Call Report. The patient’s end tidal CO2, O2 saturation levels, RRtotal, Vt, FiO2, PEEP and PIPs must be continuously monitored and recorded *Pressure Support Ventilation (PSV) on the LTV 1200 is achieved by setting the ventilator to Pressure + SIMV/CPAP + Breath Rate to zero (--).
pages.clinical: <tab1>• Not applicable</tab1>

drug_cards.section: Assessment and Preparation of the Ventilated Patient
dose_route:
Confirm ETT placement (ETCO2 & Auscultation) and ETT depth at least 21 cm at the lips in females and 23 cm at the lips in males.
Check ETT cuff pressure 20-30 cm H2O.
Obtain baseline vital signs.
Choose mode of ventilation for patient:
<tab1>• PSV if awake & spontaneously breathing;
• AC with either PCV or VC if inadequate respirations, heavily sedated or high ventilator settings required.</tab1>
Perform leak test on ventilator circuit.
Calculate and document on the call report the ideal body weight based on measured height/gender table*
<tab1>• IBW in kg for females = 45.5 + 2.3 x [height in inches-60]
• IBW in kg for males = 50 + 2.3 x [height in inches-60]</tab1>
May use measured height from sending facility to calculate if available.
Review most recent chest film and arterial blood gas if available, and confirm ETT in good position as per sending facility CXR or sending MD or radiology report; document confirmation:
<tab1>• If unable to confirm ETT position with CXR as above consider delay time to obtain CXR versus clinical impact to patient in delayed transport</tab1>Document ETT size and depth at the lips.Confirm serum bicarbonate level from electrolytes, ABG or VBG (require ETCO2 target adjustment if HCO3 < 15 or > 35).Determine if patient has the following:
<tab1>• Normal lung physiology
• COPD/Asthma
• Lung Injury/ARDS
• Severe Metabolic Acidosis</tab1></left>

Start Assist Control Adjust pressure control or set volume to achieve Vt 6-8 ml/kg. Frequency 10-20/min to achieve ETCO2 of 35-45 mm Hg unless increased ICP= ETC02 33-38. Initiate FiO2 at 1.0 or match FiO2 from sending facility if available, wean FiO2 to keep SpO2 94-98%. Minimum PEEP of 5 for all patients, may increase up to 10 if required to match sending facility ventilator setting or to achieve O2 saturation target. Titrate FiO2 and PEEP to achieve O2 sat 94-98% target (88-92% if known CO2 retainer and matches target at sending facility). Adjust inspiratory time to achieve I:E ratio between 1:1.5 and 1:3.0 (may use longer I time to improve mean airway pressure and subsequently oxygenation, shorter I time if obstructive airway disease). Adjust sensitivity to trigger with respiratory effort (default is 3 lpm). PIP < 30 cm H20. Plateau < 30 cm H20. DeltaP (PPlat - PEEP) < 15 cm H2O If already well ventilated, consider maintaining current setting. Ensure BVM with external PEEP valve and manometer available for duration of transport. Target ETCO2 35-45 unless increased ICP + ETCO2 33-38 Target Vt to 6-8 mL/kg IBW. Adjust PSV/PCV (or set Vt in VC) to obtain Vt target. Adjust RR 10-20 to achieve target ETCO2 once target Vt obtained. NOTE: minimum PSV 8 cm H2O. Chronically ventilated patients may have PSV as low as 5/5 provided tidal volume according to IBW is maintained. Must maintain plateau/peak airway pressure < 30 cm H20 with adjustments.
Alarm Guidelines
Set High pressure 5-10 cm H20 above the PIP. Set Low pressure alarm 5-10 cm H20 below PIP. Set minute ventilation alarm at 75% of actual VE.

<left>Record and monitor the following ventilator parameters:
<tab1>• Target Vt/IBW
• Pressure or Volume control
• AC/SIMV/PSV
• Sensitivity
• Frequency
• Tidal volume
• Minute ventilation
• PEEP
• Pressure support
• Inspiratory time
• I:E ratio
• ETCO2
• FiO2
• Peak Inspiratory Pressure
• Mean Airway Pressure</tab1></left>

<left>Monitor ETCO2 and capnographic waveforms throughout transport.
Monitor mean arterial pressure changes related to potential ventilator changes during transport.
Consider checking plateau pressure and/or auto PEEP if concerned about lung compliance or air trapping. NOTE: to perform either maneuver requires an apneic patient

Maximum cuff pressure = 20-30 cm H2O OR Minimum Occluding Volume (MOV) - inflate until you hear no leak at PIP Tracheal perfusion pressure = 30mmHg (arterial) / 18mmHg (venous) Recommended cuff pressure is just enough to seal the trachea at PIP/MOV. Check cuff pressure using a manometer. Palpating the pilot balloon is not an acceptable determination of cuff pressure.

To prevent or treat autoPEEP Use low to normal frequency (8-12 breaths/min). Titrate frequency to maximize I:E ratio > 1:4 – 1:5 allowing for long expiratory time. Use low tidal volume 4-6 mL/kg of ideal body weight. PEEP 5 cm H2O Adjust inspiratory time < 1.0 second (0.7-1.0). Keep Plateau Pressure < 30 cm H20. Titrate parameters to achieve Sp02 91%-94% or in keeping with patient’s baseline status.

Severe airway obstruction may not allow complete expiration prior to the next delivered breath. Severe airway obstruction may result in PIPs > 30 cm H2O to achieve target Vt 4-6 ml/kg IBW
Intrinsic or autoPEEP develops, leading to worsening hypoxia, hypercapnea and hypotension.
Monitor capnographic waveform for sloped expiratory rise indicating airflow obstruction.
Consider Salbutamol & Ipratropium Bromide via MDI.
If Difficult to ventilate or oxygenate consider: Permissive hypercapnia Consider matching auto-PEEP; i.e. set PEEP to 2-3 cm H2O < then measured autoPEEP

<tab1>• Consider use of Magnesium Sulfate IV infusion
• Consider Ketamine IV infusion
• Consider paralysis
• Optimize analgosedation and paralysis in combination with above therapies</tab1>

Initial frequency 20-26/min. Adjust to maintain target ETCO2.
Initial Vt 6 mL/kg. Adjust Vt based on plateau pressures:
<tab1>• If plateau > 30 cmH20 then decrease Vt to 4-5 ml/kg
• If plateau < 30 cmH20 then Vt may be increased to maximum 8 ml/kg</tab1>
Start with FIO2 of 1.0 and PEEP of 5-8 cm H20<tab1>• If SpO2 >98% then decrease FIO2;
• If SpO2 < 90% then increase PEEP to 10 and then incrementally by 2 cm H20 to maximum of 20.Refer to the ARDSnet PEEP/FiO2 table</tab1>
Check tidal volume with every adjustmentmadeto pressure control and PEEPsettings. Watch for drop in Vt indicating potential excessive PEEP).
VC: Check peak/ plateau pressure with every change in PEEP and tidal volume.
Keep plateau pressure < 30 cm H20.
Keep Driving Pressure (DeltaP, Plat-PEEP) < 15 cm H2O
Minimize FIO2 ideally < 0.60.
Adjust PEEP ideally above lower inflection point and/or to achieve SpO2 > 92%.
Allow for permissive hypercapnia.
ETCO2 45-80 mm Hg (based on ABG target pH 7.20-7.25).</left>

Inflamed lungs with decreased compliance and increased dead space are prone to atelectasis, barotrauma and volutrauma. Do not decrease tidal volumes below 4 mL/kg Increased I:E ratio can improve oxygenation by increasing mean airway pressure and helping to maintain PEEP. I:E ratio’s < 1:2 should be considered. For example: • 1:1.8 • 1:1.6 • 1:1.4 • 1:1.2 • 1:1.0

drug_cards.title: Simplified table (minimum target PEEP for increased FiO2)
drug_cards.notes: Use this table for guidance when addressing ongoing hypoxia and increasing oxygenation support, do not use for initial ventilator settings

pages.title: Adult - Non-Invasive Positive Pressure Ventilation (NPPV)
pages.indications: <tab1>• Conscious patient able to protect airway in respiratory distress</tab1>
pages.contraindications:
<tab1>• NPPV is contraindicated in patients with active vomiting and in those that are unable to manage airway secretions
• Decreased level of consciousness/severe agitation
• Inability to protect airway
• Repeated hemoptysis
• Cardiac arrest or respiratory arrest
• Immediate need for endotracheal intubation
• Upper airway obstruction
• Facial trauma
• Recent esophagostomy</tab1>
<title>Relative Contraindications</title>
<tab1>• Hemodynamic instability</tab1>
pages.clinical: • Patch first if the patient has altered mentation or is lethargic • NIPPV may be of benefit in hypercarbia from ventilatory failure even with altered mental status • For agitated patients consider TMP discussion for sedation Understanding the numbers • iPAP = Inspiratory Positive Airway Pressure (Peak inspiratory pressure - PIP). iPAP is the sum of PEEP and PS; e.g. if the PEEP = 5 and you set a PS of 10, the resultant iPAP = 15 • ePAP = Expiratory Positive Airway Pressure (PEEP) • Pressure Support = the difference between iPAP & ePAP • CPAP = when iPAP equals ePAP (example: CPAP 5=PS 0/PEEP 5)

drug_cards.title: Initiation of CPAP/NPPV
dose_route: Initial Settings iPAP 10 cmH2O/ePAP 5 cm H2O MAX iPAP 20 cmH2O/ePAP 10 cmH2O

drug_cards.title: Maintenance of NIPPV Initiated By Sending Facility
dose_route: <center>Patient's hemodynamics and ventilation status stable on current settings</center>

pages.title: Adult - High Flow Nasal Cannula Therapy (HFNC)
pages.indications:
<tab1>• Refractory hypoxemia despite optimized conventional nasal cannula and/or non-rebreather mask O2 therapy in individuals with an intact, acceptable respiratory drive
</tab1><tab2>o Adults: SpO2 <90%</tab2><tab1>
• COPD/CHF exacerbation requiring a minimal amount of PEEP
• Palliative respiratory support with no endotracheal intubation or non-invasive ventilation (NIV) support in the care plan</tab1>
pages.contraindications:
<tab1>• A definitive airway is required for airway protection and/or respiratory support characterized by acute respiratory acidosis
• Complete nasal airway obstruction
• Use with caution if there is a history of facial trauma, acute sinusitis or otitis
</tab1><title>Complications</title><tab1>
• Unmeasured PEEP may result in pneumothorax or lung hyperinflation</tab1>
pages.clinical: Prior to transport perform a 10 minute trial period off HFNC, using a NRB + conventional NC to determine patient tolerance when AC power is not available for HFNC; e.g. transfer between ambulance and hospital. A successful trial is confirmed by patient SpO2 > 88%. If battery power is not a concern, there is no requirement to conduct this trial.

dose_route: <center>Initiate treatment at 30 lpm and titrate flow and FiO2 to achieve SpO2 > 94%</center>

pages.title: Adult - Inhaled Epoprostenol (Flolan®)
pages.indications:
<tab1>• Severe ARDS with refractory hypoxemia
• Pulmonary hypertension
• Right heart failure</tab1>
pages.contraindications:
<tab1>• Severe left ventricular systolic dysfunction
• Pulmonary hemorrhage
</tab1><title>Relative Contraindications:</title><tab1>
• Thrombocytopenia (platelets <50 x 109/L )
• Active hemorrhage
• Pulmonary edema
• Hypotension</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Inhaled Epoprostenol (Flolan®)
dose_route:
<center>0-50 nanograms (ng)/kg/min nebulized*
(*FIXED RATE - SHOULD NOT be titrated during transport)</center>

pages.title: Adult - Transport of Patients in the Prone Position
pages.indications:
<tab1>• Severe ARDS (P:F < 150), FiO2 > 0.6, and PEEP > 5 cmH2O with failed supine ventilation</tab1>
<title>General Principles:</title>
<tab1>• Mechanically ventilate as per Ornge Clinical Practice Guidelines for ARDS
• Maintain Sedation and Analgesia as per Ornge Sedation and Pain Management of Ventilated Patients Guidelines to target a sedation score of -4 (i.e., deep sedation)
• Maintain paralysis during transport (see below)</tab1>
pages.clinical:
<title>Cardiac Arrest in Prone Position</title><tab1>
• In the event of cardiac arrest, if the rhythm is shockable, defibrillation should be initiated immediately. Ensure defibrillation pads are applied in an anterior-posterior orientation prior to initiating transport.
• CPR will not be performed in the prone position and the paramedic team should not attempt to return the patient supine to do chest compressions.
• The decision of transporting a prone patient will be made in conjunction with the TMP, sending physician, and/or receiving physician and the best attempt made to inform the substitute decision maker of the risks and limitations of the transport.</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Transport of Patients in Prone Positioning
dose_route: <center>Follow Prone-to-Prone Transfer Process as outlined in the Prone Ventilation Operational and Clinical Guidelines</center>

drug_cards.title: Rocuronium
dose_route:
<center>0.6 mg/kg IV to initiate paralysis
Then
0.3 mg/kg IV q 20 minutes
AND/OR
10-15 microgram/kg/min to maintain paralysis</center>

drug_cards.title: Cisatracurium
dose_route:
<center>0.1-0.2 mg/kg IV to initiate paralysis then 0.03 mg/kg IV q 30 minutes
AND/OR
1-10 microgram/kg/min to maintain paralysis (usual starting dose 3 microgram/kg/min after initiating paralysis</center>

pages.title: Adult - Pre-Transfer Anxiolysis
pages.indications:
For a patient demonstrating or verbalizing the symptoms of transfer anxiety and:
<tab1>• GCS of 15
• MAP ≥ 70 mmHg
• No concurrent sedation or parenteral analgesia being administered</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>
pages.clinical: <tab1>• Not applicable</tab1>

pages.title: Adult - Agitated/Combative Patient
pages.indications:
<tab1>• In the event that a patient becomes agitated or combative, thereby endangering themselves or crew, ALL Paramedics are expected to: <u>Physically restrain the patient as per MOHLTC Basic Life Support - Patient Care Standards</u>
• Assess the patient for medical causes of agitation (i.e. hypoxemia, hypoglycemia, etc.)</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>
pages.clinical:
<tab1>• In patients with a primary psychiatric diagnosis, if time permits, contact TMP for Haloperidol (Haldol TM)
• Notify the Flight Crew immediately if in an aircraft</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Midazolam (Versed)
dose_route: MAP > 70 0.05 mg/kg IV/IO OR 0.1 mg/kg IM q 5 minutes prn MAX dose 0.2 mg/kg IV/IM/IO

drug_cards.title: Ketamine
drug_cards.notes: *High IV doses of Ketamine should be given slow push (over > 1 minute) to reduce risk of apnea *Consider administering using a 50 ml NS bag over 5-10 minutes

drug_cards.title: Haloperidol (Haldol)
dose_route:
<center>2.5 mg - 5.0 mg IV every 5-10 minutes
to a Maximum of 30 mg
 or
10 mg of Haloperidol IM
(repeat, if required, x1 and patch with TMP)</center>
drug_cards.notes: NOTE: In patients > 65 years of age, start with 2.5 mg

pages.title: Adult - Analgesia: Moderate to Severe Pain
pages.indications: All patients should be assessed fro level of pain using a 10 point scale (0 = no pain while 10 = maximum pain) At least two scores should be documented on all patients and a score must be documented before and after analgesia is provided to the patient
pages.contraindications: Allergy or sensitivity to the medication
pages.treatment: Patch when maximum amount given or for any other concerns
pages.clinical:
<tab1>• Total acetaminophen dose is not to exceed the lesser of a total of 75 mg/kg or 4 grams in 24 hours
• Ketamine for analgesia should be administered slowly using a mini bag or slow IVP if necessary. Adverse events are reduced substantially (46% vs 17%) if given slowly vs IVP.<tab1>

drug_cards.title: Ibuprofen (Advil)
dose_route: <center>Contraindication: Impaired renal function, active bleeding, NSAID in the past 4-6 hours</center>

drug_cards.title: Acetaminophen (Tylenol)
dose_route: 40 to 60 kg 15 mg/kg PO/PR q 4 hours prn ≥ 60 kg 975-1000 mg PO/PR q 4 hours prn MAX 75 mg/kg OR 4 grams in 24 hours

drug_cards.title: Toradol (Ketorolac)
dose_route: <center>Contraindication: Impaired renal function, active bleeding, NSAID in the past 4-6 hours</center>

drug_cards.title: Toradol (Ketorolac)
dose_route: <center>Contraindication: Impaired renal function, active bleeding, NSAID in the past 4-6 hours</center>

drug_cards.title: fentaNYL (Sublimaze)
dose_route: MAP > 70 MAP > 80 (high ICP, ischemic stroke or spinal cord injury) 25-50 microgram IV/IO q 10 minutes prn MAX 300 microgram

drug_cards.title: Morphine
dose_route: MAP > 70 MAP > 80 (high ICP, ischemic stroke or spinal cord injury) 2-4 mg IV/IO q 20 minutes prn MAX 10 mg

drug_cards.title: Ketamine
dose_route: <center>Ketamine is <u>not</u> a first line agent for analgesia in normotensive patients but can be considered early for multiple trauma patients or those with concerning hemodynamic status</center>

<center>0.1 mg/kg IV/IO q 5 minutes PRN
MAX total dose 0.5 mg/kg
MAP > 60</center>

pages.title: Pain Scale For Adult Intubated Patients
content: Presence of frowning, brow lowering, orbit tightening and levator contraction
All of the facial movements plus eyelid tightly closed
Does not move at all (does not necessarily mean absence of pain)
Slow, cautious movements, touching or rubbing the pain site, seeking attention through movements
Pulling tube, attempting to sit up, moving limbs/thrashing, not following commands, striking at staff, trying to climb out of bed
Muscle tension: Evaluated by passive flexion and extension of upper extremities
Strong resistance to passive movements, inability to complete them
Compliance with the ventilator (intubated patients) OR Vocalization (extubated patients)
Asynchrony: blocking ventilation, alarms frequently activated
Talking in normal tone or no sound
Talking in normal tone or no sound

pages.title: Sedation Scale For Adults (RASS Score)
content: Tolerating ventilator mostly; needs sedation and analgesia when stimulated and moved
Tolerating ventilator mostly; needs sedation and analgesia when stimulated and moved
Wakes < 10s; Eye contact; Simple commands only
Tolerating ventilator mostly; needs sedation and analgesia when stimulated and moved
Reaches for ETT, mild distress, coughing
Moves to voice; no eye contact
Coughing when moved but tolerates ventilation otherwise
Pupils dilated, ↑↑HR or ↑↑BP with external stimulation (1)
No response to voice; Moves spontaneously and to physical stimuli
Minimal or no reaction (pupils, HR, BP) with stimulation (1)
Minimal or no response to voice or noxious stimuli
Minimal or no response to ventilator
Minimal or no reaction (pupils, HR, BP) with stimulation (1)

pages.title: Adult - Sedation and Pain Management for Intubated and Ventilated Patients
pages.indications: <tab1>• When a patient is clinically stable, intubated and mechanically or manually ventilated, the ACP(f), and CCP may administer the following for sedation and analgesia</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>
pages.treatment: Infusions are preferred to repeat bolus dosing for sedation and analgesia wherever possible. A bolus dose of sedation or analgesia should only be considered when infusion dosing is increased and rapid therapeutic effect is required. Caution should be used with bolus dosing as this may increase the risk of sedation induced hypotension. All mechanically ventilated patients should receive analgesia with either Ketamine or FentaNYL.ACP(f), CCP, PCCP and PCCN may choose and give ONE analgesic along with ONE of the following sedative agents; patch when maximum amount given, or for any other concerns
pages.clinical:
<tab1>• <u>All patients</u> (intubated or non-Intubated) receiving analgosedation must be constantly monitored using a continuous ETCO2 gas-sampling device that displays both a value and waveform, and have sedation and pain score documented q 30 minutes throughout transport
• For recurrent hypotension requiring intervention TMP contact is recommended</tab1>

drug_cards.title: fentaNYL (Sublimaze) if MAP > 70 (MAP > 80 if high ICP, ischemic stroke or spinal cord injury)
dose_route:
<center>50-100 microgram IV/IM prn q 5 minutes
Maximum cumulative dose for the boluses as above cannot exceed 3 microgram/kg/hr</center>

drug_cards.title: Midazolam (Versed) if MAP > 70 (MAP > 80 if high ICP, ischemic stroke or spinal cord injury)
dose_route:
<center>1-2 mg IV prn q 5 minutes
MAX dose 0.15 mg/kg/hr</center>

drug_cards.title: Propofol (Diprivan) if MAP > 70 **Caution in elderly patients ** (MAP > 80 if high ICP, ischemic stroke or spinal cord injury)
dose_route:
<center>Titration of the infusion is preferred however, may give additional boluses of
10-20 mg IV q 5 minutes prn if rapid effect is required, and as long as
MAP > 70 mmHg
<red>Exercise caution as bolus doses increase risk of hypotension</red></center>
Titration of the infusion is preferred 1-5 mg/kg/hr Titrate in increments of 0.3 mg/kg/hr q 5 minutes prn if MAP > 70

drug_cards.title: Ketamine if MAP > 60 (if MAP < 60 Mandatory patch*) (MAP > 80 if high ICP, ischemic stroke or spinal cord injury)
dose_route:
<center>1-2 mg/kg IV over 1 minute x 1 dose
followed by 0.5 mg/kg q 20 minutes prn</center>
drug_cards.notes: *If MAP < 50 patch to consider other therapies

drug_cards.title: Phenylephrine (Neosynephrine)
dose_route: MAP < 65 MAP < 80 (high ICP, ischemic stroke or spinal cord injury) 100 microgram IV/IO X 3 q 3 minutes prn MAX 300 microgram

pages.title: Adult - Post Intubation Paralysis
pages.indications: • Patients with known difficult airways • Facilitate and optimize mechanical ventilation and oxygenation for transport • Sedation and Analgesia must be administered in conjunction with muscle relaxation
pages.contraindications:
<tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication
• Inadequate sedation/analgesia</tab1>
pages.clinical:
<tab1>• In patients with known difficult airways, muscle relaxation is strongly recommended post intubation to ensure minimal risk for loss of ETT in transport
• Complete history and physical examination (including baseline neurologic assessment) must be completed
• Baseline assessment of vital signs and level of paralysis should be obtained and documented to detect and record the patient’s subsequent response to paralysis
• Muscle relaxants will hide the motor component of seizures. In cases of status epilepticus or risk of seizures, use paralysis as a last resort and in conjunction with anticonvulsant/sedative infusions. Monitor for autonomic manifestations of seizures
• Proper securing of the ETT is paramount</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Rocuronium (Zemuron)
dose_route:
0.6 mg/kg IV/IO
then
0.3 mg/kg IV/IO q 20 minutes prn

pages.title: Adult - Non-Traumatic Cardiac Arrest
pages.indications: <tab1>• Adult patient is vital signs absent (VSA) due to non-traumatic cause</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Not applicable</tab1>
pages.clinical:
<tab1>• PCP(f) may apply the Medical Directives for the management of cardiac arrest with semi-automated defibrillation
• TMP patch prior to initiating transport of patient in cardiac arrest for consideration of TOR</tab1>

dose_route: Initiate the appropriate algorithm based upon the presenting ECG rhythm
Initiate the appropriate algorithm based upon the presenting ECG rhythm

pages.title: Adult - Severe Hypothermic Arrest
pages.indications: <tab1>Adult patient to be vital signs absent (VSA) and Hypothermic defined as temperature < 30°C, or presumed to be so based on environmental circumstances.</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Not applicable</tab1>
pages.clinical: <tab1>• Not applicable</tab1>

dose_route: Initiate the appropriate algorithm based upon the presenting ECG rhythm

pages.title: Adult - Post Arrest Return of Spontaneous Circulation (ROSC)
pages.indications: <tab1>• ROSC</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Not applicable</tab1>
pages.clinical:
<tab1>• Reminder that Targeted Temperature Management (TTM) is Mandatory. Temperatures should be maintained between 34°C and 36°C during TTM
• Document attempts to control temperature
• Maintain temperature 34-36°C, ETC02 35-40 mmHg, SpO2 94-98%</tab1>

dose_route: Initiate the appropriate algorithm based upon the presenting ECG rhythm

pages.title: Adult - Acute Coronary Syndrome
pages.indications:
<tab1>• Suspected cardiac ischemia</tab1>
<title>Conditions for Nitroglycerin Administration</title>
<tab1>• Patient is ≥ 40 kg
• MAP ≥ 70 mmHg
• Heart rate is > 60 beats and < 160 bpm
• Patient is alert
• Patients under the age of 18 requires a TMP patch</tab1>
<title>Contraindications for Nitroglycerin Administration</title>
<tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to nitrates
• Patient has used any phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors (Sildenafil [Viagra or Revatio], tadalafil [Cialis], or Vardenafil [Levitra]) in the last 48 hours (these agents are commonly used for erectile dysfunction and are also used in pulmonary hypertension)
• 12 lead ECG compatible with Right Ventricular MI</tab1>
pages.clinical:
<tab1>• In the setting of acute coronary syndrome fentaNYL is the preferred analgesic
• Consider Plavix in NSTEMI patients
• Patch if PTT parameters (above) fall outside norm</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Nitroglycerin SL *
dose_route: MAP >70 0.4 mg SL spray q 5 minutes MAX of 6 doses
drug_cards.notes: *Single PCP(f): Initiate then patch

drug_cards.title: Initiate Nitroglycerin IV MAP > 70
dose_route:
<center>10 microgram/min
MAX 100 microgram/min
Titrate q 5 minutes in 5 microgram/min increments for ischemic chest pain
Maintain Nitroglycerin infusion during transport</center>

drug_cards.title: Maintain Nitroglycerin IV
dose_route:
<center>Maintain nitroglycerin infusion during transport under conditions listed below
• The infusion was initiated by the sending facility
• The infusion rate is ≤ 100 microgram/min IV
• No change in patient condition during transport</center>

drug_cards.title: Acetylsalicylic Acid (ASA)
dose_route: <center>160 mg PO, chewed and swallowed (two 80 mg chewable tablets)</center>

<tab1>• No allergy to ASA
• No current active bleeding
• No evidence of CVA or head injury within 24 hours prior to onset of chest pain
• No history of asthma exacerbation from ASA ingestion</tab1>

drug_cards.section: Fentanyl is the preferred analgesic for ischemic chest pain.
drug_cards.title: fentaNYL (Sublimaze)
dose_route: MAP ≥ 70 25-50 microgram IV/IO q 5 minutes prn MAX 300 microgram

drug_cards.title: Metoprolol
dose_route:
<center>5 mg IV/IO q 5 minutes
MAX 15 mg
If the patient is hypertensive or tachycardic</center>

drug_cards.title: Maintain Heparin*
dose_route:
<center>Maintain Heparin infusion rate from sending if last PTT within therapeutic range of Ornge or sending hospital nomogram,
OR
if infusion initiated and no post-initiation PTT available yet</center>

drug_cards.title: Initiate Heparin*
dose_route:
<center>60 units/kg IV bolus
MAX 5,000 units
then
INITIATE Infusion 12 units/kg/hr IV
Titrate dose relative to aPTT</center>

drug_cards.title: Heparin Nomogram for Patients NOT Receiving Thrombolytics or Glycoprotein IIb/IIIa Inhibitors
dose_route:
<center>Next aPTT
(from the time rate was changed)</center>
If aPTT is greater than 120 OR less than 50 x 2 consecutive blood samples, patch TMP
drug_cards.notes: *Contraindications to Heparin: • Active bleeding • History of Heparin induced thrombocytopenia

pages.title: Adult - ST Elevation MI (STEMI)
pages.indications: <tab1>• STEMI as defined by ECG changes</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• See TNK Checklist</tab1>
pages.treatment: In patients being transported for acute cardiac intervention (emergent PCI) initiate Medical Directive and load and go. Initiate patch in transport or pre-patch prior to arrival whenever possible.
pages.clinical:
<tab1>• No thrombolysis will be administered unless the TMP confirms diagnosis based on clinical and ECG findings and gives the order to proceed. It is preferred that the TMP reviews the ECG but if not possible and paramedic is confident of positive ECG criteria then a verbal confirmation on patch with TMP is adequate
• Obtain 12 Lead ECG every 15 minutes or prn for duration of transport
• Consider Plavix, Ticagrelor
• Patch if PTT parameters (above) fall outside norm</tab1>

dose_route: Initiate appropriate treatment based on algorithm below

drug_cards.title: TNKase
dose_route: Patient’s Weight (kg) < 60 kg ≥ 60 to < 70 kg ≥ 70 to < 80 kg ≥ 80 to < 90 kg > 90 kg

drug_cards.title: Initiate Heparin* Concurrent Use When Thrombolytics Given:
dose_route:
<center>60 units/kg IV bolus
MAX 4,000 units
then
INITIATE Infusion 12 units/kg/hr IV
MAX 1,000 units/hr
Titrate infusion using Heparin Nomogram</center>

drug_cards.title: Heparin Nomogram for Patients NOT Receiving Thrombolytics or Glycoprotein IIb/IIIa Inhibitors
dose_route:
<center>Next aPTT
(from the time rate was changed)</center>
If aPTT is greater than 120 OR less than 50 x 2 consecutive blood samples, patch TMP
drug_cards.notes: *Contraindications to Heparin: • Active bleeding • History of Heparin induced thrombocytopenia

pages.title: Contraindications to Thrombolytics
content: Any prior intracranial hemorrhage, hemorrhagic stroke, or stroke of unknown origin
Known structural cerebral vascular lesion (i.e. arteriovenous malformation)
Active bleeding or bleeding diathesis (excluding menses)
Gastrointestinal bleeding within the last month
Major trauma/surgery/head injury within three months
<b>* Must be 'No' to all Absolute Criteria to proceed
Patient within 90 minutes of PCI centre from scene, consider direct transport for PCI OR 120 minutes from PCI centre if in a community hospital
History of chronic, severe, poorly controlled hypertension
Severe uncontrolled hypertension on presentation (SBP greater than 180 mmHg or DBP > than 110 mmHg)†
History of prior ischemic stroke or transient ischemic attack within six months, dementia, or known intracranial pathology not covered in contraindications
Traumatic or prolonged CPR (> than ten minutes)
Recent internal bleeding (within two to four weeks)
Pregnancy or within one week postpartum
Current use of anticoagulants: the higher the INR, the higher the risk of bleeding
* Must have this information available for the TMP to help weigh risk/benefit of thrombolytic therapy
†Could be an absolute contraindication in low-risk patients with MI

pages.title: Adult - Cardiogenic Pulmonary Edema
pages.indications:
<tab1>• Initial MAP ≥ 70 mmHg and SBP > 100
AND
• Heart Rate is ≥ 60 but < 160 bpm</tab1>
pages.contraindications:
<tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication
• No IV
• Nitroglycerin: Any phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors use (Sildeafil [Viagra or Revatio], Tadalafil [Cialis], or Vardenafil [Levitra]) in the last 48 hours (these agents are commonly used for erectile dysfunction and are also used in pulmonary hypertension)</tab1>
pages.clinical:
<tab1>• If a patient presents with moderate to severe respiratory distress and the Paramedic suspects the patient is in acute pulmonary edema
• Reassess & document vitals between doses
• Discontinue Nitroglycerin if the BP or heart rate parameters for Nitroglycerin are no longer met
• Check blood pressure before administering each subsequent dose of Nitroglycerin</tab1>

drug_cards.title: CPAP/NPPV
dose_route: Initial Setting iPAP 10 cmH2O/ePAP 5 cmH2O MAX iPAP 20 cmH2O/ePAP 10 cmH2O

drug_cards.title: Nitroglycerin*
dose_route:
<center>0.4 mg SL spray
q 5 minutes prn
MAX of 6 doses</center>
drug_cards.notes: *Single PCP(f): Initiate then patch

drug_cards.title: Nitroglycerin (Tridil) IV Infusion (for severe pulmonary edema)
dose_route:
<center>Initiate 10 microgram/min IV
titrate in 5 microgram/min increments q 5 minutes
MAX 200 microgram/min</center>

drug_cards.title: Furosemide (Lasix)
dose_route:
<center>40 mg IV or double patients usual total daily dose
MAX of 160 mg</center>

pages.title: Adult - Cardiogenic Shock
pages.indications: <tab1>• Cardiogenic shock</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>
pages.clinical:
<tab1>• In general, titration of Norepinephrine should be based upon MAPs whereas response to DOBUTamine should be based on perfusion and clinical parameters such as urine output
• MAP parameters in cardiogenic shock should be targeted to low normal levels, MAP 60-65 and less than 80 provided there are signs of adequate perfusion</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Normal Saline or Ringers Lactate
dose_route:
<center>250 mL IV/IO bolus PRN, MAX 10 ml/kg
Target MAP > 65</center>

drug_cards.title: DOBUTamine (Dobutrex)
dose_route:
<center>5-20 microgram/kg/min IV/IO
Initiate at 5 microgram/kg/min
Minimum MAP 60 prior to initiating</center>

pages.title: Adult - Intra-Aortic Balloon Pump (IABP) Auxiliary Medical Directive
pages.indications:
<tab1>• A CCP may provide the treatment prescribed in this auxiliary medical directive if certified and authorized
• Patient > 18 years old
• Patient > 40 kg
• Patient must already be on Intra-Aortic Balloon Pump (IABP) at the sending hospital</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Not applicable</tab1>
pages.treatment:
<tab1>• Paramedics are required to perform IABP specific assessments
</tab1><tab2>o Verify balloon position and size
o Identify balloon tip on x-ray
o Assess for distal pulses in insertion limb
o Assess for urine output
o Identify if catheter is fiber optic
o Identify trigger being used
o Assess IABP waveform
o Ensure catheter is sutured securely in place</tab2>
Paramedics are required to Patch to obtain orders when providing IABP care.
pages.clinical:
<tab1>• 1 IABP certified paramedic with CCP partner
• Paramedics are not permitted to advance or remove IABP catheters
• Paramedics are required to ensure transport IABP is in ready state, fully charged, appropriate helium levels, paper role, and appropriate cables
• Document sending facility IABP parameters</tab1>

dose_route:
<tab1><left>• Both paramedics at the bedside for transition to transport IABP
• Put IABP in 1:2 ratio
• Select trigger
• Assess and adjust 3 rules of timing to achieve ideal waveform and augmentation
• Run a recording strip
• Maintain head of bed no higher than 30 degrees
• Keep insertion limb straight
• Ensure no blood is present in the catheter
• Return IABP ratio to 1:1 or 1:2 matching setting from sending</left></tab1>

<tab1><left>• Exercise caution to protect IABP catheter from being pulled.
• Continuously monitor the patient and the performance of the IABP, make adjustments as required to maintain good augmentation
• Run a recorder strip at the start of transport and again at the end of transport
• Plug IABP into vehicle power source to conserve IABP internal battery</left></tab1>

<tab1><left>• Paramedics to ensure safe transfer of IABP care with accepting hospital staff
• Run final strip prior to transfer
• Document as required on ACR among other care the specifics of the IABP</left></tab1>

pages.title: Adult - Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation (ECMO) Auxiliary Medical Directive
pages.indications:
<tab1>• Veno-venous (VV) or Veno-arterial (VA) Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation (ECMO)/Extracorporeal Life Support (ECLS)
• Accompanied by ECMO team including ECMO physician
• A CCP may provide the treatment prescribed in this auxiliary medical directive if certified and authorized
• Age > 16
• Successful cannula placement and ECMO initiation</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Not applicable</tab1>
pages.clinical:
<tab1>• The CCP must patch with the TMP if medications are required beyond those provided for in these Medical Directives; if medication doses are required beyond those provided for in these medical directives; or in the case of ECMO failure requiring use of emergency medical directives (as soon as practical and safe to do so taking into account workload to stabilize patient)
• The CCP may also provide all additional care covered by routine CCP level medical directives</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Mechanical ventilation*
dose_route:
<tab1>• Pressure Control Ventilation
• RR 10 breaths/min**
• Pressure control 10 cmH20**
• PEEP 10 cmH20**
• FiO2 0.3
• Protective lung strategy Vt 4-5 ml/kg IBW, RR 10/min, Ti 1.0 sec</tab1>

** or to an initial maximum of 20-20-20 (RR-PC-PEEP) as requested by the ECMO physician

Keep plateau pressures less than 30 cm H20 with adjustments unless ECMO failure (see ECMO failure emergency medical directives)
May titrate FiO2 up to 1.0 and PEEP up to 20 if requested by ECMO physician
 Given that PaCO2 and PaO2 determined by ECMO rather than mechanical ventilation, there is no need to titrate mechanical ventilation during transport (please refer to the Emergency Medical Directive for ECMO/ECLS Failure portion at the end of the Medical Directive for orders in the event of ECMO failure)
drug_cards.notes: *Confirm ETT placement on chest X-ray from sending facility

drug_cards.section: Circulation and Fluids Continue any of the following medications being administered at the time of initiation of ECMO and/or add/titrate at the request of the ECMO physician within the prescribed ranges below. Match dose from sending facility as starting dose.
drug_cards.title: Norepinephrine (Levophed)
dose_route:
<center>0-0.5 microgram/kg/min IV
Match sending facility for starting dose
Target MAP > 65</center>

drug_cards.title: Vasopressin
dose_route:
<center>0.02-0.1 units/min IV
Match sending facility for starting dose
Target MAP > 65</center>

drug_cards.title: EPINEPHrine Target MAP > 65
dose_route:
<center>0-0.5 microgram/kg/min
Match sending facility for starting dose</center>
drug_cards.notes:
*to prepare push-dose EPINEPHrine (i.e., 10 microgram/mL concentration)
<tab1>1. Draw 100 microgram (i.e. 1 mL of 1:10,000) EPINEPHrine and dilute in 9 mL of Normal Saline</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Phenylephrine Target MAP > 65
dose_route:
<center>0-500 microgram/min
Match sending facility for starting dose</center>

drug_cards.title: Fluids
dose_route:
<center>Bolus 20 mL/kg RL or NS q 15 minutes prn to keep MAP > 65 and/or if rising vasopressor requirements
Assess for signs of fluid overload between each bolus and hold further fluid boluses if signs fluid overload
May substitute sodium bicarbonate (3 amps in 850 cc D5W) instead of NS/RL as bolus fluid 20 ml/kg at request of ECMO physician for metabolic acidosis</center>

<center>Maintenance infusion RL or NS at 0-150 cc/hr (choice as per ECMO physician and/or to match sending facility, RL preferred)
May switch to sodium bicarbonate infusion (3 amps in 850 mL D5W) at 0-150 cc/hr</center>

drug_cards.title: Packed Red Blood Cells (PRBC)
dose_route: <center>Transfuse PRBC at request of ECMO physician if Hb < 70 g/L or if active bleeding; medics may bring PRBC from sending facility to have on standby if available and requested by ECMO physician</center>

drug_cards.title: Cisatracurium
dose_route:
<center>0.1-0.2 mg/kg IV to initiate paralysis
0.03 mg/kg IV q 30 minutes prn</center>

<center>1-10 microgram/kg/min
(usual starting dose 3 microgram/kg/min
after initiating paralysis)</center>

drug_cards.title: Rocuronium (Zemuron)
dose_route:
<center>0.6 mg/kg IV to initiate paralysis
0.3 mg/kg IV q 20 minutes</center>
drug_cards.notes: *Must have analgesia (fentaNYL) plus sedation (propofol, midazolam or ketamine) running at all times while paralyzed

drug_cards.section: Additional Medications At request of ECMO physician
drug_cards.title: Unfractionated Heparin
dose_route:
<center>May give 5000 units IV bolus upon cannulation;
repeat as requested by ECMO physician/perfusionist</center>

<center>0-3000 units/hr IV, continue dose from sending;
adjust as requested by ECMO physician based on
PTT/ACT as directed by ECMO physician/perfusionist
(target ACT 160-180 sec)</center>

pages.title: Adult - Emergency Medical Directive for ECMO/ECLS Failure
pages.indications:
<tab1>• Cardiac Arrest
• ECMO/ECLS equipment failure
• Failure to Oxygenate
• Uncontrolled bleeding/Volume loss/Exsanguination</tab1>

drug_cards.section: May use all above ECMO medical directives, standard CCP Medical Directives, and in addition:
drug_cards.title: Mechanical ventilation
dose_route:
<tab1>• FiO2 1.0 and titrate down for O2 saturation > 95%
• PEEP 5-20, may increase settings to aim for Vt 6-8 ml/kg
• PIP < 30 (may increase to 40 if unable to achieve targets with settings otherwise)
• Titrate RR to achieve EtCO2 50-60 target
• I:E 1:1 if possible for oxygenation failure</tab1>
drug_cards.notes: **Mandatory TMP patch if ECMO failure as soon as possible after initiation of ECMO failure orders taking into account immediate patient care needs

drug_cards.title: ECMO Failure
dose_route:
<tab1>• Cardiac arrest
• ECMO/ECLS equipment failure
• Failure to oxygenate
• Uncontrolled bleeding/volume loss/exsanguination</tab1>

pages.title: Adult - Symptomatic Bradycardia
pages.indications: <tab1>• Symptomatic Bradycardia with a pulse</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Atropine
dose_route: <center>0.5 mg IV/IO initial dose (repeat q 3-5 minutes to max total dose 3 mg)</center>

drug_cards.title: Dopamine
drug_cards.notes: Patients with bradycardia requiring transcutaneous (TC) pacing who are conscious and aware of their surroundings may require sedation and analgesia prior to TC pacing.

drug_cards.title: Transcutaneous Cardiac Pacing
dose_route:
<center>Set pacing rate at 70
Start output at 10 milliamps (mA) and increase to achieve electrical capture with a pulse (mechanical capture)
Once mechanical capture has been confirmed increase mA by 10%
Confirm the presence of a pulse and assess blood pressure and perfusion</center>

drug_cards.title: Procedural Sedation
dose_route: MAP ≥ 65 Ketamine 0.1 mg/kg, MAX 0.5 mg/kg OR Versed 0.05 mg/kg fentaNYL 1 micgrogram/kg

pages.title: Adult - Transvenous Cardiac Pacing
pages.indications: <tab1>• Transvenous pacing, if initiated at the sending facility</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Not applicable</tab1>
pages.clinical:
<tab1>• Monitor the cardiac rhythm and ensure the catheter/cable is carefully secured to prevent inadvertent tension or traction on the line
• Ideal capture threshold is < 1. High outputs are an indication of misplaced wires or more serious pathology that can be more prone to capture failure and need for TCP vs other interventions</tab1>

dose_route: Maintain transvenous pacing if initiated at sending facility (Initial pacing settings will reflect sending facility settings)
Any alteration of settings to be discussed with TMP

pages.title: Adult - Symptomatic Atrial Fibrillation/Flutter
pages.indications:
<tab1>• Symptomatic Atrial Flutter
• Symptomatic Atrial Fibrillation</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>
pages.treatment: Patients with Atrial Fibrillation/Flutter where emergency synchronized cardioversion is indicated who are conscious and aware of their surroundings may require sedation and analgesia first. Below are medical directives for sedation and analgesia for cardioversion. Patients that are peri-arrest or hemodynamically unstable can be immediately managed with synchronized cardioversion without sedation or analgesia

drug_cards.title: Procedural Sedation
dose_route: MAP ≥ 65 Ketamine 0.1 mg/kg, MAX 0.5 mg/kg OR Versed 0.05 mg/kg fentaNYL 1 micgrogram/kg

pages.title: Adult - Paroxysmal Supraventricular Tachycardia (PSVT)
pages.indications: <tab1>• Paroxysmal Supraventricular Tachycardia (PSVT)</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>
pages.treatment: Patients with PSVT with a pulse who are conscious and aware of their surroundings may require sedation and analgesia prior to cardioversion. Below are directives for sedation and analgesia for cardioversion. Patients that are peri-arrest or hemodynamically unstable can be immediately cardioverted with synchronized cardioversion (without sedation or analgesia).
pages.clinical: <tab1>• Adenosine dose should be decreased if patient taking dipyridamole or carbamazepine, dose should be decreased if given by central line; caution in asthma</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Procedural Sedation
dose_route: MAP ≥ 65 Ketamine 0.1 mg/kg, MAX 0.5 mg/kg OR Versed 0.05 mg/kg fentaNYL 1 micgrogram/kg

drug_cards.title: Adenosine
dose_route:
<center>6 mg rapid IV/IO with 20 mL NS flush
Repeat at 12 mg x 1 prn</center>

pages.title: Adult - Ventricular Tachycardia with Perfusion
pages.indications: <tab1>• Ventricular Tachycardia (VT) with a pulse</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>
pages.treatment: Patients with VT with a pulse who are conscious and aware of their surroundings may require sedation and analgesia prior to cardioversion. Below are directives for sedation and analgesia for cardioversion. Patients that are peri-arrest or hemodynamically unstable can be immediately cardioverted with synchronized cardioversion without sedation or analgesia.
pages.clinical:
<tab1>• Consider early Magnesium IV for polymorphic VT
• Polymorphic VT should prompt consideration if clinically appropriate for toxicologic exposure which have specific antidote therapies (Ex: Beta blockers in hydrocarbon toxicity). Emergent TMP consultation is indicated
• Consider hyperkalemia medical directive (167) for wide complex tachycardia/lethal arrythmias</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Procedural Sedation
dose_route: MAP ≥ 65 Ketamine 0.1 mg/kg, MAX 0.5 mg/kg OR Versed 0.05 mg/kg fentaNYL 1 micgrogram/kg

drug_cards.title: Amiodarone (Cordarone)
dose_route:
<center>150 mg IV over 10 minutes
(may repeat x1 as adjunct to cardioversion)</center>

pages.title: Adult - Intravenous Line Initiation
pages.indications: <tab1>• Actual or potential need for intravenous or fluid therapy</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Suspected fracture proximal to the IV site</tab1>
pages.clinical: <tab1>• *A PCP(f) may provide the treatment prescribed in this auxiliary medical directive if certified and authorized</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Initiate IV
dose_route: <center>MAX of 2 peripheral IV lines may be established</center>

pages.title: Adult - Intraosseous Initiation and Maintenance
pages.indications: • Inadequate intravenous access for resuscitation • Unable to obtain intravenous access after two (2) attempts or 90 seconds
pages.contraindications:
<tab1>• Known or suspected fracture, injury, deformity, or infection overlying the proposed insertion site
• Absence of adequate anatomic landmarks
• Previous IO insertion in the bone in the past 48 hours
• Known or suspected fracture of affected limb</tab1>
pages.clinical: <tab1>• Resuscitation indicates the process of correcting physiological disorders in the acutely unwell patient. The patient need not be in cardiac arrest to qualify for IO insertion</tab1>

dose_route: Initiate the appropriate intervention based upon the presenting condition

pages.title: Adult - Intraosseous Vascular Access Analgesia
pages.indications: <tab1>• Patient requiring intraosseous (IO) needle access and responsive to pain</tab1>
pages.contraindications:
<tab1>• Sino-atrial disorders
• All grades of AV block, Stokes-Adams syndrome, Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome
• Acute porphyria
• Hypersensitivity to another local anesthetic of the amide type</tab1>
pages.clinical:
<tab1>• After the second lidocaine dose is given, medication or fluids may be administered under pressure as required
• Can consider administering again in 45 minutes later at the lower of the two previous doses given if discomfort re-occurs
• If extravasation occurs insert a new IO needle
• Cimetidine or beta-blockers (e.g. propranolol) may interact and cause lidocaine toxicity</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Lidocaine 2% without epinephrine
drug_cards.notes: *Administer first dose over 2 minutes then allow lidocaine to dwell for 1 minute in IO space and flush with 5-10 mL 0.9% saline Followed by second dose of lidocaine over 1 minute

pages.title: Adult - Intravenous Line Maintenance Standard: PCP(f)
pages.indications: <tab1>• Initiated by sending facility</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Not applicable</tab1>
pages.clinical:
<tab1>• To keep the vein open (TKVO)</tab1><tab2>
o The minimum flow rate to maintain IV patency for a patient ≥12 years of age is 30 mL/hr of any isotonic fluid (Normal saline or ringers lactate); or
</tab2><tab1>
• For fluid replacement
</tab1><tab2>o A maximum flow rate infused of up to 2 mL/kg/hr to a MAX of 200 mL/hr,
o Thiamine, multivitamin preparations,
o Drugs within his/her level of certification, or
o Potassium chloride (KCl) for patients ≥18 years of age, to a MAX of 10 mEq in a 250 mL or 40 mEq in a 1000 mL bag</tab2>

drug_cards.title: Maintain IV
dose_route: May transport a patient with a saline IV infusion containing thiamine, multivitamin preparations and KCl to a MAX of 40 mEq/Litre as initiated by the sending hospital and maintain at the rate set by the sending facility up to a MAX of 200 mL/hr

pages.title: Adult - Blood Sampling and Lab Value Interpretation
pages.indications:
<tab1>• To establish baseline respiratory, cardiovascular, hematological status prior to or during transport
• To monitor changes and/or deterioration in clinical status</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Not applicable</tab1>
pages.clinical:
<tab1>• Management based on these results will be via patch with the TMP
• These tests should only be completed if absolutely essential to patient management en route and will not cause unnecessary delays in transport</tab1>

dose_route: Perform venipuncture, venous blood sampling and utilize iSTAT if available Perform arterial blood sampling and utilize iSTAT if available

pages.title: Adult - Maintaining and Accessing Central Venous Lines
pages.indications:
<tab1>• Actual or potential need for intravenous medication / fluid therapy
AND
• Central venous access is available</tab1>
You may access the following types of devices:
<tab1>• Hickman
• PICC (Peripherally Inserted Central Catheter)
• Central Venous Line</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Not applicable</tab1>
pages.clinical:
<tab1>• Every lumen of a capped central line must be flushed prior to transport to ensure that they are patent and functional as per the Ornge Medical Procedure Manual
• Venous devices that are located subcutaneously, i.e. PortaCath or similar devices MAY NOT to be accessed</tab1>

dose_route: Must be capped for transport Devices must not be accessed by the PCP(f)

pages.title: Adult - Arterial Line Maintenance and Monitoring
pages.indications: <tab1>• Established arterial line</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Not applicable</tab1>
pages.clinical:
<tab1>• NS is the preferred solution for arterial lines with flush / pressure bag / transducer system unless sending facility has it heparinized in which case, one should continue as per sending
• Arterial lines are not to be capped or locked due to the risk of thrombosis. Instead, it must be removed if not transduced
• Arterial lines are calibrated (zeroed) with any changes in level of bed &/or position of head of bed to transducer, if waveform changes and with IV tubing changes
• Ensure all connections are tight , line is secured (ie arm board) and limb properly restrained as required
• Blood backing up the transducer tubing from the patient may indicate a leak, crack or loose connections</tab1>

dose_route: Perform blood sampling and utilize iSTAT if available
Monitor and transduce an established arterial line

pages.title: Adult - Pulmonary Artery Catheters Auxiliary Medical Directive
pages.indications: <tab1>• A CCP may provide the treatment prescribed in this auxiliary medical directive if certified and authorized</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Not applicable</tab1>
pages.clinical:
<tab1>• If the arterial line and PA catheter cannot be simultaneously monitored then the arterial line will be monitored and the PA line will be removed. Authorized CCPs may remove the PA catheters prior to transport if required. The catheter must be completely removed, not just pulled back into the right atrium or SVC. The introducer (cordis) should be left in-situ and a plug inserted so that a new PA line may be inserted at the receiving facility
• If the patient must be transported with a PA catheter in place, and no authorized CCP is available, the sending facility must send an appropriate escort with the responsibility for care and monitoring of the PA catheter under the sending facility staff</tab1>

pages.title: Adult - Stroke
pages.indications: <tab1>• Acute stroke</tab1>
pages.contraindications:
<tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication
• Traumatic head injury
• Blood glucose < 4 mmol</tab1>
pages.clinical: <tab1>• Not applicable</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Labetalol Hold if HR < 60 bpm MAX dose 300 mg/day
dose_route:
<center>10-20 mg slow IV push q 20 minutes prn
until desired MAP achieved</center>

drug_cards.title: Hypertonic Saline (3%)
dose_route:
<center>3 mL/kg IV/IO
MAX rate of 20 mL/min
Consider if MAP < 80 mmHg</center>

pages.title: Adult - Seizures
pages.indications: <tab1>• Active Seizure</tab1>
pages.contraindications:
<tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication
• If blood glucose level ≤ 4 mmol/L, proceed with protocol for “Hypoglycemic Emergencies”.</tab1>
pages.treatment: If, on assessment, a patient is determined to be having a seizure, management of airway, breathing and circulation remain the first priority: adequate oxygenation and ventilation must be ensured.
pages.clinical: <tab1>• 0.2 micron filter must be used when administering phenyTOIN</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Midazolam (Versed) for Seizures
dose_route: 5 mg IV/IO doses repeated every 5 minutes, until seizure termination or MAX dose of 0.2 mg/kg IV/IO in total OR 10 mg IM if no IV/IO access

drug_cards.title: phenyTOIN (Dilantin)
dose_route: 20 mg/kg add to 250 mL NS IV/IO Infusion should be no faster than 25 mg/min USE NORMAL SALINE ONLY phenyTOIN will precipitate in dextrose solutions

drug_cards.title: Propofol
dose_route:
<center>50 mg IV/IO q 5 minutes prn if MAP > 70
Prepare to intubate
Followed by infusion at 0-5 mg/kg/hr</center>

pages.title: Adult - Traumatic Cardiac Arrest
pages.indications: <tab1>• Adult patient is vital signs absent (VSA) due to trauma</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Not applicable.</tab1>
pages.clinical:
<tab1>• If this is inter-facility then a STAT patch to the TMP is indicated for further management decision making
• Routinely bind pelvis if MOI suggests potential for pelvic injury
• Perform bilateral needle thoracostomy in acute traumatic arrest</tab1>

pages.title: Adult - Traumatic Brain Injury
pages.indications: <tab1>• Traumatic brain injury</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>
pages.clinical: <tab1>• Trauma patients should be kept warm with temperature > 35 degrees</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Hypertonic Saline (3%)
dose_route:
<center>3 mL/kg IV/IO
MAX rate of 20 mL/min

Consider if MAP < 80 mmHg</center>

pages.title: Adult - Spinal Cord Injury
pages.indications: <tab1>• Spinal cord injury</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Not applicable</tab1>
pages.clinical: <tab1>• Not applicable</tab1>

pages.title: Adult - Neurogenic Shock
pages.indications: <tab1>• Neurogenic shock</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>
pages.clinical: <tab1>• In neurogenic shock (if not also hypovolemic) there is sufficient alpha activity at low doses of levophed that significant reflex bradycardia may arise due to unopposed vasoconstriction and carotid body stimulation/vagal tone. In this situation, dopamine may be considered</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Atropine Sulfate (Atropine)
dose_route:
<center>0.5 mg IV/IO q 3-5 minutes prn
Total MAX dose 3 mg (whichever is less)</center>

pages.title: Adult - Traumatic Hemorrhagic Shock
pages.indications: <tab1>• Hemorrhagic shock MAP < 65 mmHg with active, ongoing and significant bleeding</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>
pages.clinical: <tab1>• Avoid hypothermia. Keep patient’s temperature above 35ºC</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Consider PRBCs and TXA
dose_route: See Blood Product Administration Medical Directive and TXA Medical Directive

pages.title: Adult - Blood Product Administration
pages.indications:
<tab1>• Hemorrhagic shock MAP < 65 mmHg with active, ongoing and significant bleeding
• Hemoglobin < 70 grams/litre with evidence of circulatory compromise
• TMP judgement</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>
pages.clinical:
<tab1>• Contact the TMP to request Packed Red Blood Cells (PRBCs) at the scene. This would only be indicated in very rare individual circumstances i.e. uncontrolled hemorrhagic shock despite adequate crystalloid resuscitation, prolonged out-of-hospital time (i.e. prolonged extrication) and no significant delay to arrival to patient caused by waiting to retrieve the blood
• Ensure all available identifiers (i.e. name, blood type, patient number, etc) are checked to ensure correct blood product transfusion
• Once any of the above products are administered, the blood product form must be completed and submitted to the receiving institution, so that they are aware
• Informed consent for blood product administration must be obtained if Ornge initiates the blood product (please refer to the consent form in the Clinical Affairs P&P manual) except in life threatening circumstances
• Please note, if immediate PRBCs are required for an unstable patient request Type O blood if available (O Negative for women of child bearing age)</tab1>

dose_route:
<center>1-2 PRBC to maintain
MAP > 65 mm Hg or Hgb > 70 as directed</center>
<center>2 U for every 2 U PRBC delivered</center>

<center>1-2 PRBC to maintain
MAP > 65 mm Hg or Hgb > 70 as directed</center>
<center>2 U for every 2 U PRBC delivered</center>

pages.title: Adult - Reversal of Warfarin/Coumadin
pages.indications:
<tab1>• Prothrombin Complex Concentrate (PCC) if emergency reversal of Warfarin therapy (intracranial bleed, emergency surgery, life threatening bleed) AND INR >1.5
• Life-threatening hemorrhage (i.e., ICH, major trauma, GI bleed requiring RBC transfusion)
• Emergency surgery</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>
pages.clinical: <tab1>• The most commonly used Prothrombin Complex Concentrate (PCC) is Octaplex but some facilities may also use Beriplex</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Prothrombin Complex Concentrate (PCC)*
dose_route: <center>Initiate or maintain the administration of PCC</center>

<center>10 mg of IV Vitamin K
(via slow IV infusion ≤ 1 mg/min)
MUST be administered either before or during the infusion of PCC for maintenance</center>

drug_cards.title: The usual dose of Octaplex is
drug_cards.notes: *PCC is a blood product and requires transfusion consent

pages.title: Adult - Direct Oral Anticoagulant/Novel Oral Anticoagulants Reversal
pages.indications:
<tab1>• Life-threatening hemorrhage (i.e., ICH, major trauma, GI bleed requiring RBC transfusion)
• Emergency surgery</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>
pages.clinical: <tab1>• Not applicable</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Idarucizumab
dose_route:
<center>5 grams (2 x 2.5 vials) in 100 mL over 10 minutes by bolus infusion
Compatible with NS</center>

drug_cards.title: Prothrombin Complex Concentrate (PCC)*
dose_route:
<center>2000 IU and repeat
2000 IU at 1 hour
if ongoing bleeding</center>
drug_cards.notes: *PCC is a blood product and requires transfusion consent

drug_cards.title: Tranexamic Acid (TXA)
dose_route: <center>1 g and repeat in 1 hours (2nd bolus of 1g in 1 hour)</center>

pages.title: Adult - Tranexamic Acid (TXA) Administration
pages.indications: <tab1>• Treatment of trauma-associated hemorrhage, management of massive bleeding, or prophylaxis of systemic or local hyperfibrinolysis</tab1>
pages.contraindications:
<tab1>• Known hypersensitivity to TXA
• Greater than 3 hours from time of injury to drug administration (for traumatic injury)</tab1>
pages.clinical: <tab1>• If active bleeding persists, additional 1 gram bolus doses of TXA may be indicated. Discuss with TMP.</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Tranexamic Acid (TXA)
dose_route:
<center>Initiate if the following indications are met:
<tab1>• Administration is limited to definite knowledge of <3 hours from time of injury
• HR > 100 bpm or SBP < 100 mmHg</center>

<center>1 gram loading dose (over 10 minutes)
repeat 1g bolus in 1 hour</center>

pages.title: Adult - Push Dose EPINEPHrine (10 mcg/ml = 1: 100 000)
pages.indications: <tab1>• Temporary improvement of circulation in peri-arrest or shock states with severe hypotension and/or bradycardia</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Patients in cardiac arrest</tab1>
pages.clinical: • Epinephrine 1: 100 000 may provide temporary stabilization while other therapies are added or adjusted/titrated Preparation of Push Dose Epinephrine - 10 mcg/ml concentration 1. Using a 10 mL syringe, draw 100 microgram (i.e. 1 mL of 1:10,000) EPINEPHrine and dilute in 9 mL of Normal Saline

drug_cards.title: EPINEPHrine (Adrenalin) 10 mcg/ml - 1: 100 000
dose_route:
<center>5-20 mcg IV/IO q 2-5 minutes PRN
Target MAP >65</center>

pages.title: Adult - Hypovolemic Shock
pages.indications: <tab1>• Hypotensive as defined by a MAP < 65 mmHg as a result of hypovolemia</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>
pages.clinical:
<tab1>• Following consultation with the TMP, volume replacement therapy, can be continued by the ACP(f), CCP and PCCP/PCCN with the intent of keeping the patient’s MAP within a normotensive range (i.e. ≥ 65 mmHg). Severe hypovolemia from blood loss should prompt consideration for early use of blood products including both packed red blood cells and fresh frozen plasma in cases of massive transfusion (see Blood Product Administration Medical Directive)
• In setting of hemorrhage consider early blood component therapy (BCT) and limit crystalloid to 1L - use NS for BCT
• Avoid crystalloid in large doses in hemorrhagic shock particularly in trauma
• Crystalloids are indicated in hemorrhagic shock if delay for blood with hypotension and altered mentation
• Consider TXA if severe hemorrhagic shock</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Normal Saline or Ringers Lactate
dose_route:
<center>20 mL/kg IV/IO bolus
MAX 1 Litre
REPEAT bolus if patient continues to be symptomatically hypotensive
Target MAP > 65</center>

drug_cards.title: Consider PRBCs and FFP
dose_route: See Blood Product Administration Medical Directive

pages.title: Adult - Septic Shock
pages.indications: <tab1>• Septic shock (MAP < 65)</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>
pages.clinical:
<tab1>• Consider 1 g CaCl in 100 mL NS/1 hour if ionized Ca < 1 or Ca < 2.0 (corrected if available)
• For patients that are profoundly hypotensive with MAP <50 or pre-arrest consider emergent TMP patch to discuss epinephrine 1: 100 000 and start Norepinephrine infusion at minimum 0.3 mcg/kg/min. Crystalloid bolus should be given concurrently with push dose pressors and/or Norepinephrine infusion initiation
• If Hydrocortisone not available consider Methylprednisolone 125 mg IV/IO</tab1>

pages.title: Adult - Extravasation of Vasopressors from Peripheral IV Infusion
pages.indications: <tab1>• Extravasation of norepinephrine, epinephrine, dopamine, DOBUTamine, vasopressin, or phenylephrine from peripheral IV site</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>
pages.clinical:
<tab1>• Extravasation of vasopressors may potentially cause necrosis of tissue around the IV site or possibly compartment syndrome. Whenever possible, a central line should be used. If peripheral IV access is the only route available, try to avoid the hand or wrist whenever possible. Any IV pressor site should be kept visible and examined q 15 minutes to assess for extravasation
• The phentolamine may cause systemic hypotension, but should be addressed if the secondary IV site is running the original pressor</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Phentolamine (within 12 hour of extravasation)
dose_route: <center>0.1 mg/kg to a max of 10 mg in 9 mL of NS (using a different syringe should be injected) half through the problematic IV catheter over 60 seconds and half as a Sub Q injection around the site using a 25G – 30G needle into any area where tissue discoloration or swelling is seen</center>

pages.title: Adult - Nausea, Vomiting and Motion Sickness
pages.indications: <tab1>• Nausea, vomiting, or prevention of motion sickness</tab1>
pages.contraindications:
<tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication
• Received dimenhyDRINATE or Ondansetron within the last 4 hours
• Prolonged QT interval or concomitant use of other drugs that may prolong the QT interval (specific to Ondansetron)</tab1>
pages.clinical: <tab1>• dimenhyDRINATE should be administered SLOW IV push to prevent vertigo, weakness and dizziness</tab1>

drug_cards.title: dimenhyDRINATE (Gravol)
dose_route:
<center>50 mg IM/PO
OR
50 mg/10 mL NS over ≥ 5 minutes</center>

drug_cards.title: Ondansetron (Zofran)*
dose_route:
<center>4 mg IM q 4-8 hours prn
OR
4 mg IV in 50-100 mL NS over ≥ 15 minutes q 4-8 hours prn</center>
drug_cards.notes: *Black box warnings due to risk of prolonged QT • All IV doses must be diluted in 50–100 mL of saline or other compatible fluid • All IV doses must be infused over no less than 15 minutes

pages.title: Adult - Gastric (NG or OG) Tubes
pages.indications:
<tab1>• Actual or anticipated need to evacuate gastric contents
• Intubated and ventilated patients or SGA being used for transport</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Nasogastric -Patients presenting with facial smash or suspected basal skull fracture</tab1>
pages.clinical: <tab1>• Insertion should not delay transport</tab1>

dose_route: Maintenance Only Ensure the gastric tube is appropriately located via auscultation
Insertion and/or Maintenance Ensure the gastric tube is appropriately located via auscultation Confirm by partner prior to departure

pages.title: Adult - Gastrointestinal Bleed
pages.indications: <tab1>• Treatment of gastrointestinal bleed</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>
pages.clinical: • Consider Ceftrixone 1 g IV/IO

drug_cards.title: Consider PRBC
dose_route: See Blood Product Administration Medical Directive
The paramedic may continue a Pantoprazole and/or Octreotide infusion from sending facility

drug_cards.title: Octreotide
dose_route:
<center>50 microgram IV/IO over 3 minutes
followed by infusion</center>

pages.title: Adult - Gastroesophageal Balloon Tamponade Devices (Blakemore Tube)
pages.indications: <tab1>• Patients who have a gastroesophageal balloon tamponade device (i.e. Sengstaken-Blakemore Tube) in place</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Not applicable</tab1>
pages.clinical:
<tab1>• Ideally the patient should be intubated and sedated to increase patient tolerance and comfort
• Maintain 1 kg of traction with BVM mask and forceps
• Esophageal balloon pressure should be monitored and should remain between 25-45 mmHg. (35-60 cmH2O) Conversion of mmHg to cm H2O = multiply X 1.36</tab1>

dose_route: <center>If the patient is not intubated, scissors should be readily available to cut the port for balloon deflation should the tube and balloon be pulled back into the pharynx, resulting in a hypopharyngeal occlusion</center>

pages.title: Adult - Esophageal Temperature Probes
pages.indications:
