<tab1>• Continuous monitoring of core body temperature for any intubated patient with a temperature outside normal range (36.5 to 37.5oC)
• Temperature monitoring during active rewarming measures
• Continuous monitoring may be ordered by the TMP at their discretion
• Required for targeted temperature management in ROSC</tab1>
pages.contraindications:
<tab1>• Esophageal strictures
• Esophageal varices
• Esophageal perforation
• Congenital anomalies such as tracheal esophageal fistula
• Post-Operative tonsil and adenoidectomy patients
• Facial trauma
• Patients receiving Anticoagulants. Anticoagulants include but are not limited to: IV Heparin, Warfarin (Coumadin), Enoxaparin (Lovenox)</tab1>
pages.clinical: <tab1>• It is preferable to assess position of probe using a CXR but should not delay transport</tab1>

dose_route: Insert and monitor core temperature with Esophageal Temperature probe

pages.title: Adult - Urinary Catheter Insertion and Maintenance
pages.indications:
<tab1>• For monitoring urine output
• For urinary tract obstruction</tab1>
pages.contraindications:
<tab1>• Blood at the urethral meatus
• Perineal or scrotal hematoma
• Suspected urethral tear
• High riding prostate</tab1>
pages.clinical:
<tab1>• Urinary catheter removal can only be performed by the ACP(f), CCP and PCCP/PCCN
• If during transport the catheter becomes obstructed contact the TMP</tab1>

pages.title: Adult - Fever
pages.indications: <tab1>• Fever - temperature >38oC</tab1>
pages.contraindications:
<tab1>• Acetaminophen within the last 4 hours
• Ibuprofen:</tab1><tab2>
• NSAID or Ibuprofen use within previous 6 hours
• Patient on anticoagulation therapy
• Current active bleeding
• Hx of peptic ulcer disease or GI bleed
• Pregnant
• If asthmatic, no prior use of ASA or other NSAIDs
• CVA or TBI in the previous 24 hours
• Known renal impairment
• Active vomiting
• Unable to tolerate oral medication</tab2>
pages.clinical: <tab1>• Total acetaminophen dose in 24 hours is not to exceed the lesser of 75 mg/kg or 4 grams</tab1>

pages.title: Adult - Anaphylaxis
pages.indications:
<tab1>• Confirmed or suspected history of exposure to an allergen
AND
• Signs and symptoms of a severe life-threatening anaphylactic reaction</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>
pages.clinical:
<tab1>• May need EPINEPHrine infusion for refractory anaphylaxis
• Consider histamine antagonists such as Ranitidine</tab1>

drug_cards.title: EPINEPHrine (Adrenaline) 1:1000 Solution
dose_route:
<center>0.01 mg/kg IM in anterolateral thigh
(min 0.1 mg to max 0.5 mg)
May repeat x 1 after 5 minutes
Use caution in elderly and those with CAD</center>

drug_cards.title: Salbutamol (Ventolin) Solution Via Nebulized Aerosol (2.5 mg/2.5 mL)
drug_cards.notes: *Total volume of Salbutamol and Normal Saline should be 5.0 mL

drug_cards.title: Salbutamol (Ventolin) MDI (100 microgram/puff)
dose_route:
<center>8 puffs
(4 breaths or 45 seconds between each administration)
may repeat x 3 q 5-15 minutes prn</center>
drug_cards.notes: *Total volume of Salbutamol and Normal Saline should be 5.0 mL

drug_cards.section: For Persistent Hypotension with MAP <65 mm Hg
drug_cards.title: Normal Saline or Ringers Lactate
dose_route:
<center>20 mL/kg IV/IO bolus
MAX 1 Litre
REPEAT bolus if patient continues to be symptomatically hypotensive
Target MAP > 65</center>

pages.title: Adult - Hypoglycemic Emergencies
pages.indications:
<tab1>• Altered level of consciousness (GCS <14)
• Blood glucose < 4 mmol</tab1>
pages.contraindications:
<tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication
• Pheochromocytoma is a contraindication to glucagon</tab1>
pages.clinical: <tab1>• Not applicable</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Glucagon for Hypoglycemia
dose_route: Repeat blood glucose measurement 20 minutes after the administration of Glucagon Follow with oral carbohydrates ASAP if LOC permits (i.e. a meal or snack)

drug_cards.title: 50% Dextrose for Hypoglycemia
dose_route:
<center>25 g of D50W IV
(50 mL D50W)</center>
Repeat blood glucose measurement 10 minutes after the administration of Dextrose IV Follow with oral carbohydrates ASAP if LOC permits

drug_cards.section: After the administration of Glucagon and/or Dextrose, if an IV is present, the ACP(f), and CCP should begin an infusion of D10W or D10NS at 100 mL/hr (the accompanying preparation table identifies the process for creating a 10% Dextrose solution).
drug_cards.title: 10% Dextrose Solution
dose_route: <center>25 mL of 1 prefilled syringe of D50W</center>

drug_cards.title: Thiamine (Vitamin B1)
dose_route:
<center>100 mg IV
(mini bag or push)
or
100 mg IM</center>

pages.title: Adult - Hyperkalemia
pages.indications: <tab1>• Patient exhibiting signs and symptoms of hyperkalemia</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>
pages.clinical: <tab1>• Not applicable</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Calcium Gluconate (10%)
dose_route:
<center>20 mg/kg IV/IO (Max single dose 1g) - q 5 minutes PRN
Max TOTAL dose 40 mg/kg or 2g (lesser of)
Administer over 2-3 minutes
Additional doses may be required, discuss with TMP</center>
drug_cards.notes: OR - if patient in cardiac arrest/pre-arrest

drug_cards.title: Calcium Chloride (Calcijet)
dose_route:
<center>20 mg/kg IV/IO q 5 minutes prn
Single MAX dose 1g over 20 minutes PIV (5 minutes if central line)
Total MAX dose 40 mg/kg or 2g (lesser of)
Slow IVP is appropriate in the setting of cardiac arrest/pre-arrest</center>

drug_cards.title: Dextrose
dose_route: <center>25 g IV/IO - Repeat X 1 if required</center>

drug_cards.title: Salbutamol (Ventolin) MDI (100 microgram/puff)
dose_route:
<center>16 puffs x 2 q 5-15 minutes prn
(45 seconds between each administration)</center>

drug_cards.title: 3% Mucomyst (Acetylcysteine)* Dosage Guide and Preparation for IV Administration (reference CPS)
drug_cards.notes: *Please refer to MucomystTM (acetylcysteine) Drug Monographs profile

pages.clinical: • *If local reaction or rash occurs: Stop the infusion temporarily, treat with antihistamines, ventolin prn, then restart infusion at ½ the rate • Mandatory Patch required to initiate an acetylcysteine infusion • The ACP(f), CCP and PCCP/PCCN may maintain the administration of a MucomystTM (acetylcysteine) infusion as per the above table for an Acetaminophen overdose in the following circumstances: ◦ The infusion was initiated by the sending facility ◦ Ingested or suspected ingestion of Acetaminophen dose is greater or equal to: • 10 g TOTAL OR • 200 mg/kg ideal body weight ◦ The rate of infusion is in accordance with the accompanying dosage table and preparation guide ◦ The rate of infusion cannot be altered by the Paramedic unless ordered by the Transport Medicine Physician Guidelines to Prepare a 3% Intravenous N-Acetylcysteine Bag As part of the Poison Centre’s treatment recommendations for the acetaminophen-poisoned patient, a 3 % nacetylcysteine solution will need to be prepared. The following are instructions on how to prepare this solution in D5W. Patient is > 40 kg • Remove 150 ml from a 1000 ml bag of D5W • Add 150 ml of 20% IV N-Acetylcysteine to the remaining 850 ml in the D5W bag ◦ 150 ml X 200 mg/ml = 30 000 mg of N-Acetylcysteine ◦ 30 000 mg in 1000 ml yields a final solution with 30 mg/ml or 3% NOTES: 1. 20% IV N-Acetylcysteine is equivalent to 200 mg/ml 2. The 3% solution is slightly hyperosmolar but still within the safety margin for administration via a peripheral vein 3. It is recognized that any particular bag of IV fluid could have excessive fluid more than advertised. It is of little consequence when making this 3% solution. Assume a finished volume as advertised on the bag Mixing is important to ensure uniform distribution of N-Acetylcysteine in infusion solution

pages.title: Obstetrics - Pre-eclampsia / Eclampsia
pages.indications:
<tab1>• Symptoms of pre-eclampsia/eclampsia and pregnant or post—partum within 28 days
• Pre-eclampsia with severe features is defined as including Proteinuria, Platelets <100,000, a doubling of the serum creatinine, LFT 2x normal, pulmonary edema, or cerebral or visual symptoms</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>
pages.treatment: If, on assessment, a patient is determined to be having a seizure, management of airway, breathing and circulation remain the first priority: adequate oxygenation and ventilation must be ensured.
pages.clinical:
<tab1>• Eclamptic seizures are almost always self-limiting and seldom last longer than three to four minutes (usual duration 60 to 75 seconds). Magnesium loading dose is used to prevent recurrent seizures
• The magnesium dosage regimen should not cause toxicity in normal renal function
• In event of magnesium toxicity (i.e. respiratory depression/paralysis, severe hypotension) give calcium chloride
• Magnesium sulphate is recommended as prophylaxis against eclampsia in women with severe preeclampsia
• Routine monitoring of serum magnesium levels is not recommended
• Phenytoin and benzodiazepines should not be used for eclampsia prophylaxis or treatment, unless there is a contraindication to magnesium sulphate or it is ineffective</tab1>

Further advanced measures for active management of the third stage may be done by the CCP and PCCP/PCCN who has been trained, via contact with the TMP or either prospective or retrospective orders if contact with the TMP is impossible or cannot be obtained quickly</tab1>

pages.title: Ornge Emergency Birth Pre-Delivery Checklist
content: NeoTee with O2 supply connected & tested Neo-Tee Pressure Adjustments 1. Adjust flowmeter to 10 lpm 2. Adjust PIP, by occluding both patient & PEEP/CPAP outflow ports 3. Adjust PEEP/CPAP (5 cm H2O) by occluding only the patient outflow port
Infant BVM + PEEP valve + pressure manometer
CO2 infant size adapter or infant size colormetric CO2 indicator
2 x Cord clamps (multiple gestations 2 clamps per neonate)
Plastic bag (1 per neonate <32 wks GA)
Suction source, LSU or wall (set 80 – 100 mm Hg)
Pre-draw 2 doses of 10 u oxytocin in 2 separate 3 ml flashpoint IM syringes
Prepare 40 u oxytocin in 1000 ml 0.9% NS
Pre-draw 1 ETT dose of Epinephrine 1:10,000 in 3 ml syringe based on GA
Pre-draw 3 IV doses of Epinephrine 1:10,000 in 1 ml syringes based on GA

Prepare 10% dextrose in water
<tab1>o Waste 25ml from a 250ml bag of D5W and add 25 ml of D50W</tab1>
*If actual weight is known or a scale is available, neonate should be weighed & correct weight based dose administered

pages.title: Controlled Intubation Checklist
content: Hemodynamics Optimized - Hypotension + Metabolic Acidosis Addressed
Patient Positioned - Ear to Sternal Notch
Cardiac Monitor - NIBP (q 2 minutes), SpO2, EtCO2
Drug/Doses - induce, paralyze, post ETI analgosedation
BVM + PEEP + ETCO2 waveform / colorimetric CO2 (as indicated)
Cricothyrotomy Assessment if > 12 years of age
Tube depth confirmed with ETCO2 waveform, cuff pressure

pages.title: Paediatric - Supraglottic Airway
pages.indications:
<tab1>• Weight >2 kg
• Need for ventilatory assistance OR airway control AND
• Other airway management is inadequate OR ineffective OR unsuccessful</tab1>
pages.contraindications:
<tab1>• Intact gag reflex
• Caustic ingestion
• Active vomiting</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Supraglottic Airway
dose_route:
Insert Airway
MAX 2 attempts
Following two (2) failed attempts at supraglottic airway insertion, recommended 2 person BVM with oral/nasal pharyngeal airway management

pages.clinical:
<tab1>• Supraglottic airway should be the initial airway strategy in out of hospital cardiac arrest unless endotracheal intubation is deemed more appropriate by the paramedic
• Endotracheal intubation is usually preferred for secure airway management in the non cardiac arrest patient. In this setting, SGA is considered a rescue device if BLS airway/ventilation and other advanced airway maneuvers have been unsuccessful
• Confirm placement with ETCO2</tab1>

<tab1>• Add Normal Saline to Atrovent and Salbutamol dose to make a final volume of 3 mL. Atrovent should not be given alone. Nebulized Atrovent is given with Salbutamol dose.
• Side effects of Magnesium Sulfate include hypotension, muscle fatigue and acute pulmonary edema; monitor BP and respiratory status closely
• Consider IV Salbutamol in severe asthma exacerbations; monitor heart rate and rhythm, glucose (hyperglycemia) and electrolytes (hypokalemia)</tab1>

pages.title: Paediatric - Croup – Suspected Cases
pages.indications:
<tab1>• A current history of an upper respiratory infection with a “barking” cough
AND
• Stridor at rest, or marked accessory muscle use, or an altered level of consciousness, or cyanosis</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>

drug_cards.title: EPINEPHrine (Adrenalin) Nebulized (1:1000 solution)
dose_route:
<center>0.5 mg/dose
Dilute dose to 3mL in Normal Saline</center>

<center>2.5 mg/dose
Dilute dose to 3 mL in Normal Saline</center>

drug_cards.title: Dexamethasone (Decadron)
dose_route:
<center>0.6 mg/kg/dose PO, IM, IV
MAX 12 mg</center>

<center>Administer orally if patient able to swallow
or
If unable to tolerate oral administration due to respiratory distress and no IV access, administer IM</center>

pages.clinical:
<tab1>• Repeat the administration of EPINEPHrine nebulized using the same dose if no improvement is observed in ten minutes following the first treatment
• For patients with HR > 200/min prior to EPINEPHrine nebulization, continue to monitor heart rate and rhythm; exclude arrhythmias and evaluate need for acute fluid resuscitation</tab1>

pages.title: Paediatric - Tension Pneumothorax
pages.indications:
<tab1>• Severe respiratory distress in the setting of chest trauma with hemodynamic compromise
OR
• Traumatic VSA
OR
• Severe hemodynamic compromise with positive pressure ventilation particularly with altitude in trauma or asthma
OR
• Either chest trauma or severe asthma and hemodynamic instability and one of the following:</tab1>
<tab2>o Decreased/absent breath sounds
o Altered LOC
o Cyanosis
o JVD (not seen in young children)
o Hyper resonance on affected side
o Tracheal shift (late sign)</tab2>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Not applicable</tab1>

dose_route: <center>Consider differential diagnosis and decompress if high probability of tension pneumothorax</center>

pages.clinical:
<tab1>• The patient must be seen as soon as possible at an appropriate facility for the insertion of chest tube(s)
• Consider differential diagnosis:
</tab1><tab2>o Mainstem intubation
o Pleural effusion
o Hemothorax
o Consolidated pneumonia
o Autopeep
o Dynamic hyperinflation</tab2>

pages.title: Paediatric - Maintenance of Chest Tubes
pages.indications: <tab1>• Initiated by sending facility</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Not applicable</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Maintain chest drainage systems during the call to keep the drainage system clear
dose_route: <center>If the patient’s chest tube was maintained by suction at the sending facility, the Paramedic may maintain suction to no greater than -20 cm H2O</center>
<center>If the patient’s chest tube was maintained by gravity drainage, the Paramedic should maintain gravity drainage to underwater seal</center>

pages.clinical: <tab1>• A Heimlich flutter valve is mandatory for transport if no drainage system has been implemented</tab1>

pages.title: Paediatric - Initiating or Maintaining Mechanical Ventilation
pages.indications: <tab1>• Need for mechanical ventilation</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• None</tab1>

dose_route: Perform leak test on ventilator circuit. Obtain baseline vital signs, including ETCO2. Confirm ETT placement (direct visualization if required, auscultation, and ETCO2) and ETT depth: Oral ETT depth(cm) • 1 month: 9-10 cm • 6 months: 10-12 cm • 1 year: 12-14 • 2 to 12 years: ETT size x 3 Check cuff pressure < 20 cm H2O after tube placement, and again in flight. Review indications for mechanical ventilation: • Respiratory failure (apnea/respiratory arrest, inadequate ventilation, inadequate oxygenation) • Cardiac insufficiency/shock • Neurologic dysfunction – cerebral hypoventilation/frequent apneas, GCS < 8, and inability to protect airway Review most recent chest film, CXR confirmation reported/ ETT depth & lung fields reviewed if done, or confirm in good position. Review blood gas if available. Document ETT size and depth (distance at the lips). Keep bag-valve mask, with peep valve and pressure manometer available for the duration of transport. Paediatric ETTs should be secured according to Ornge Policy & Procedures prior to transport. Ensure NG/ or OG tubes inserted.

Select mode of ventilation for patient (PSV if awake & spontaneously breathing or AC/SIMV if unable to breathe, heavily sedated or high ventilator settings required). SIMV PC + PS/AC to achieve • Target Vt 6-8 mL/kg. SIMV VC + PS/AC to achieve • Target Vt 6-8 mL/kg. PS general starting point 10 cm H2O • Range 5-20 cm H2O to achieve • Target Vt 6-8 ml/kg. Frequency (breaths per minute): • 1 month - 1 year 20-30 • 1 - 6 years 15-25 • > 6 years 15-20 PEEP (cm H2O): • Minimum PEEP of 5 for all patients. • Pulmonary Disease 5-15 • Abdominal Distention 5-15 (Ascites, bowel obstruction) Inspiratory time: • 1 month–1 year 0.50-0.70 • 1-6 years 0.60-0.90 • > 6 years 0.70-1.0 May use longer I-time to improve mean airway pressure and subsequently oxygenation. In obstructive airway disease, to increase Te, reduce RR to achieve I:E ratio 1:4 or 1:5. Reduced Ti is not recommended due to the risk of reduced Vt, requiring increased PIP and potential for barotrauma. Match FiO2 requirements from sending facility or target SpO2 >92% Adjust sensitivity to trigger with respiratory effort (normally 3). PIP < 30 cmH20 Plateau pressure < 30 cmH20 If already well ventilated, consider starting with referral ventilator settings. i.e. Pulmonary disease, ETT leaks i.e. Head trauma (no ETT leak) Target ETCO2 35-45 (or target ETCO2 as ordered by Paediatric TMP based on clinical diagnosis).
Alarm Guidelines
Set high pressure 5-10 cmH20 above the PIP. Set low pressure alarm 5-10 cmH20 below PIP. Set minute ventilation alarm at 75% of actual VE.

Document and monitor the following ventilator parameters:
<tab1>• Mode: AC, SIMV or PSV
• Pressure or Volume control
• Sensitivity
• Frequency
• Tidal volume
• Minute ventilation
• PIP
• PEEP
• Pressure support
• Mean airway pressure
• Inspiratory time
• I:E ratio
• FiO2

Monitor EtCO2 and capnographic waveforms throughout transport.
Monitor ventilator synchrony, work of breathing, chest rise and fall.
Monitor mean arterial pressure changes related to potential ventilator changes during transport.
Consider checking plateau pressure or auto PEEP if concerned about lung compliance or air trapping.

Recommended cuff pressure is just enough to seal the trachea.
Cuff pressure should be carefully adjusted to obtain a leak free seal at a pressure < 20 cm H2O.
Recheck cuff pressure in flight.

Prevent or treat autoPEEP Start PEEP at 5 cm H20 Use low frequency 8-12 breaths/min to a maximum of 16 breaths/min. Titrate frequency to maximize I:E ratio 1:4 to 1:5 allowing for long expiratory time. Adjust inspiratory time 0.75-1.0 based on age/weight. Use low tidal volume 4-6 mL/kg. Keep plateau pressure < 30 cmH20. Titrate ventilator parameters to achieve SpO2 >92%.

Intrinsic or autoPEEP can lead to worsening hypoxia, hypercapnia and hypotension. Severe airway obstruction may not allow complete expiration prior to the next delivered breath.nMonitor capnographic waveform for sloped expiratory rise indicating airflow obstruction. Difficult to ventilate/oxygenate: Optimize sedation; Consider muscle relaxing the patient Permissive Hypercapnia; Discuss with TMP regarding use of PEEP

Start PEEP at 5 cm H2O and titrate up as needed if FiO2 > 60%.
Use low frequency half of normal rate for patient age.
Set proper I-time for age/weight.
I:E ratio 1:3 to 1:4.
Tidal volumes 6-8 mL/kg.
Keep plateau pressure < 30 cmH2O.
Titrate Ventilator parameters to achieve SpO2 >92%.

Permissive hypercapnia.
Assess adequacy of expiratory phase.
Aim to avoid or minimize hyperinflation.
Optimize sedation

Tidal volumes 6-8 mL/kg. Adjust Vt based on plateau pressures.
Start PEEP at 8 cm H2O; if FiO2 > 0.60 FiO2, titrate incremental increases in PEEP from 8 to 12 cm H2O to achieve SpO2 > 0.92. If no clinical improvements observed with increasing PEEP (increasing SpO2), STOP increasing PEEP. In severe paediatric ARDS, with no observed clinical improvements & continued SpO2 < 0.92, despite interventions, discuss further vent strategies, permissive hypoxia and hypercapnia parameters with paeds TMP
Keep plateau pressure < 30 cmH20.
FiO2 to maintain SpO2 > 90.
Inflamed lungs with decreased compliance and increased dead space are prone to atelectasis, barotrauma and volu-trauma.
Permissive hypercapnia (if pH > 7.25)
Increased I:E ratio can improve oxygenation by increasing mean airway pressure and helping to maintain PEEP. Aim for pH > 7.25 on blood gas
Avoid pulmonary de-recruitment (disconnections); may require manual recruitments using increased pressure for 30 to 40 seconds to recover.
Optimize sedation.
Consider muscle relaxing patient.

pages.clinical:
<tab1>• When mechanical ventilation is initiated, all settings and patient’s response to treatment must be documented on the Call Report
• The patient’s end tidal CO2, O2 saturation, and PIPs must be continuously monitored and recorded</tab1>

pages.title: Paediatric - Non-Invasive Positive Pressure Ventilation (NIPPV)
pages.indications:
<tab1>• Conscious patient
• Obstuctive airway disease; e.g. asthma
• Cardiac failure
• Chronic lung disease
• Acute/Chronic respiratory failure
• Neuromuscular disease
• Pneumonia</tab1>
pages.contraindications: • Paediatric patients < 9 years old • Decreased level of consciousness • Inability to protect airway • Recent gastric or esophageal surgery • Immediate need for endotracheal intubation • Pneumothorax

drug_cards.title: CPAP/BiPAP
dose_route:
Consider initiating CPAP and progressing to BiPAP as required if no improvement Initial Setting
Mild to moderate work of breathing: iPAP 6-8 cm H2O; increase to 10 cm H2O Moderate work of breathing: iPAP 10 cm H2O; increase to 15-18 cm H2O*
PEEP
If FiO2 is < 0. 40 start ePAP 5-6 cm H2O If FiO2 is > 0.40 to 0.80 start ePAP 8-10 cm H2O If FiO2 is > 0.80 start ePAP 10 cm H2O and increase to 12 cm H2O as tolerated
Invasive ventilation should be considered at these levels of O2 & support requirements

pages.clinical:
<tab1>• Titrate iPAP based on disease process requiring NIPPV e.g Asthma verses congestive heart failure (CHF) verses respiratory distress from other causes
• Start with a ePAP 5 cmH2O in asthmatic patients regardless of FiO2 needs due to air trapping and begin iPAP 8-10 cm H2O, titrating iPAP as tolerated
• Ensure mask fits securely to ensure adequate seal
• NGT/OGT to ensure gastric decompression during NIPPV
• Monitor for for leaks and mask pressure around eyes and refit as required</tab1>

pages.title: Paediatric - High Flow Nasal Cannula Therapy (HFNC)
pages.indications:
<tab1>• Any patients who would benefit from heated humidity (e.g. bronchiolitis, pneumonia, patients with tenacious secretions, tracheostomy)
• Hypoxemia, as evidenced by suboptimal oxygen saturations below acceptable patient specific ranges, despite maximum recommended flow rates while receiving traditional O2 therapy (nasal cannula, face mask or hood)
• To alleviate mild to moderate work of breathing as evidenced by the following signs & symptoms:</tab1>
<tab2>o Tachypnea, nasal flaring, in-drawing, retractions and accessory muscle use
o Agitation, confusion or anxiety
o Tachycardia and/or heart rate variability</tab2>
pages.contraindications:
<tab1>• • Acute deterioration in level of consciousness
• When positive pressure ventilation is required (poor compliance, decreased functional residual capacity).
• NHFC therapy should not be used as an alternative to positive pressure ventilation or NPPV.
• Moderate to severe respiratory distress and/or impending cardio-respiratory failure with high partial arterial pressure of carbon dioxide
• Airway obstruction (e.g. Obstructive Sleep Apnea)
• Air leak (pneumothorax, pneumomediastinum) is a potential cause for concern and should be monitored closely
• Recent post-operative esophageal surgery or suspected bowel obstruction – mechanical or functional
• Suspected or confirmed base of skull fracture
• Epistaxis</tab1>
<title>Complications:</title>
<tab1>• Unmeasured PEEP may result in lung hyperinflation, pneumothorax (rare)
• Complications of HFNC include abdominal distension, aspiration, barotrauma, and pneumothorax (rare)</tab1>

dose_route: <center>Initiate treatment at 1.5-2 L/kg/min to achieve SpO2 >92%. Contact TMP if an increase in flow is indicated and/or FiO2 requirements exceed 0.60</center>

pages.title: Paediatric - Sedation and Pain Management for Non-Ventilated Patients
pages.clinical:
<tab1>• FLACC pain scoring / assessment <red>must</red> be completed at the start of normal patient care at a frequency that aligns with the patient’s clinical state
• Pain assessment should be completed every 30 minutes as well as with significant changes in patient condition and also before and after interventions
• Use Oral route to administer medications whenever possible
• IM administration is not acceptable; use the least invasive route whenever possible
• Match analgesic to the severity of pain
• Consider using more than one class of analgesic (e.g Acetaminiphen + NSAID) to promote better pain relief; may reduce opioid requirements</tab1>

drug_cards.notes: NSAID Non steroidal anti-inflammatory drug

drug_cards.title: Acetaminophen
dose_route:
<center>500-650 mg every 4 hours PO
Max single dose 650 mg</center>

drug_cards.title: Acetaminophen
dose_route:
<center>15 mg/kg every 4 hours PO or PR
Max 1 gram
(Suspension or Suppository)</center>

drug_cards.title: 24% Sucrose
dose_route:
<center>0.1 ml PO
2 minutes prior to painful procedure</center>
drug_cards.notes: • Dose may be repeated at 5 minute intervals for prolonged procedures • Contraindicated in short-bowel syndrome, carbohydrate intolerance, unconscious or heavily sedated patients with absent gag reflex; avoid use in patients with gastrointestinal tract abnormalities (e.g. esophageal atresia or tracheal esophageal fistula), in patients at risk for aspiration. Sucrose should not be used for patients requiring ongoing analgesia

pages.title: Paediatric - Sedation and Pain Management for Intubated and Ventilated Patients
pages.indications:
<tab1>• Agitation and lability requiring intubation and ventilation
• Any patient receiving muscle relaxation
• Any patient undergoing invasive procedures
• Any patient who demonstrates positive indications of pain, tachycardia, hypertension or grimacing
• The patient must have a baseline and continuous assessment of response to the drug with heart rate, respiratory rate and blood pressure</tab1>
pages.contraindications:
<tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication
• Systolic BP below 70 + (2 x age in years)</tab1>
pages.clinical:
<tab1>• Observe patient for hemodynamic instability with analgosedation infusions
• Fentanyl is preferred for procedural pain relief or if low SBP, otherwise morphine preferred for sedation/pain management
• Systolic BP below 70 + (2 x age in years)</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Ketamine
dose_route:
<center>1-2 mg/kg slow IV push
Not to exceed 0.3-2 mg/kg/hr</center>

drug_cards.title: Propofol (Diprivan)
dose_route:
<center>Additional boluses of 0.5 mg/kg/dose
q 5 minutes prn
provided BP is normal for ag</center>

<center>0-12 mg/kg/hr titrated
by increments of 0.3 mg/kg/hr
q 5 minutes prn</center>

pages.title: FLACC (Paediatric) Behavioural Pain Assessment Scale
content: Occasional grimace or frown, withdrawn, disinterested
Frequent to constant frown, clenched jaw, quivering chin
Lying quietly, normal position, moves easily
Squirming, shifting back and forth, tense
Moans or whimpers, occasional complaint, tense
Crying steadily, screams or sobs; frequent complaints
Reassured by occasional touching, hugging, or being talked to; distractible
Severe discomfort or pain or both

pages.title: Sedation Scale For Paediatrics
content:
Spontaneously pays attention to care provider
Unsafe (biting endotracheal tube, pulling at catheters, cannot be left alone)
Unable to console
Increased movement (restless, squirming, or thrashing side-to-side, kicking legs)
May have difficulty breathing with ventilator

Coughing spontaneously
No external stimulus required to elicit response

Responds to voice/no external stimulus is required to elicit response
Drifts off/spontaneously pays attention to care provider
Intermittently unsafe
Does not consistently calm, despite 5-min attempt/unable to console
Increased movement (restless, squirming)
Spontaneous effective breathing/having difficulty breathing with ventilator

Responds to voice/no external stimulus is required to elicit response
Spontaneously pays attention to care provider
Distresses with procedures
Able to calm with comforting touch or voice when stimulus removed
Occasional movement of limbs or shifting of position/increased movement (restless, squirming)
Response to gentle touch or voice

Responds to touch/voice
Able to pay attention but drifts off after stimulation
Distresses with procedures
Able to calm with comforting touch or voice when stimulus removed
Occasional movement of limbs or shifting of position; Follows commands

Responds to noxious stimuli
Unable to pay attention to care provider
Will distress with a noxious procedure
Does not move/occasional movement of limbs or shifting of position

No response to noxious stimuli
Unable to pay attention to care provider
Does not distress with any procedure (including noxious)
Does not move
No cough or coughs only with suctioning

pages.title: Paediatric - Post Intubation Paralysis
pages.indications: • Patients with known difficult airway • To facilitate and optimize mechanical ventilation and oxygenation • Persistent hypoxia/hypoxemia despite adequate sedation • To minimize risk of accidental extubation in transport • In labile patients requiring 100% oxygen
pages.contraindications:
<tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication
• Inadequate sedation/analgesia</tab1>
pages.clinical: • In patients with known difficult airway, muscle relaxation is strongly recommended post intubation to ensure minimal risk for loss of ETT in transport • Complete history and physical examination (including baseline neurologic assessment) must be completed prior to medication administration • ETT tube confirmed to be in good position on, CXR (if available), auscultation and by EtCO2 tracing confirms ETT placement in the trachea, but does not confirm optimal positioning • Resuscitation equipment should be readily available • All patients must be on a cardiac, SpO2 and EtCO2 monitor, with frequent blood pressure monitoring (typically every 5-10 minutes unless otherwise indicated) • Baseline assessment of patient’s response (heart rate, blood pressure) to paralytic must be obtained and re-evaluated to determine need for further sedation and ongoing muscle relaxation • Sedation/analgesia must be administered in conjunction with muscle relaxation • Muscle relaxants will hide the motor component of seizures. In cases of status epilepticus or risk of seizures, paralysis should be administered as a last resort and in conjunction with anticonvulsant/sedative infusions. Monitor closely for autonomic manifestations of seizures

pages.title: Paediatric - Non-Traumatic Cardiac Arrest: PCP(f)
pages.indications: <tab1>• Vital signs absent (VSA) due to non-traumatic cause</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Vital signs present</tab1>

dose_route: Initiate the appropriate algorithm based upon the presenting ECG rhythm

pages.clinical:
<tab1>• PCP(f) may apply the Medical Directives for the management of cardiac arrest with semi-automated defibrillation
• The above chart shows all possible Joule settings based on the two types of monitors currently used by Ornge in both manual and SAED settings
• Joule settings in the algorithms above are based on the Zoll X MD Manual settings as this is the most prevalent monitor in our system
• TMP patch prior to initiating transport of patient in cardiac arrest for consideration of TOR</tab1>

pages.title: Paediatric - Non-Traumatic Cardiac Arrest: ACP(f)
pages.indications: <tab1>• Vital signs absent (VSA) due to non–traumatic cause</tab1>
pages.contraindications:
<tab1>• Vital signs present
• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>

dose_route: Initiate the appropriate algorithm based upon the presenting ECG rhythm

drug_cards.title: EPINEPHrine
dose_route:
0.01 mg/kg (0.1 mL/kg of 1:10,000 concentration)
Repeat q 3-5 min

drug_cards.title: Amiodarone
dose_route:
0.01 mg/kg (0.1 mL/kg of 1:10,000 concentration)
Repeat q 3-5 min

drug_cards.title: Lidocaine
dose_route:
Initial 1 mg/kg loading dose
Maintenance infusion 20-50 microgram/kg/min
(repeat bolus dose if infusion initiated > 15 min after initial bolus therapy)

pages.clinical: <tab1>• Lidocaine continuous IV infusion: Do not exceed 20 microgram/kg/min in patients with shock, hepatic disease, cardiac arrest or CHF</tab1>

pages.title: Neonatal Resuscitation (NRP)
pages.indications: • Neonatal vital signs absent
pages.contraindications: • Allergy or sensitivity to the medication

drug_cards.notes: *IV or UVC route is preferred

dose_route: Volume: Normal Saline and/or Blood as indicated

pages.clinical:
<tab1>• Administration of Narcan is not recommended in the initial steps of resuscitation
• *UVC/IV/IO route preferred. May consider giving one dose of EPINEPHrine via the tracheal tube (ET) while obtaining vascular access. If EPINEPHrine given by ET route and no response, as soon as UVC or IO access obtained do not wait 3-5 minutes after ET dose to administer IV dose
• Preparation for Transport:
</tab1><tab2>o Anticipate need for thermoregulation during initial steps of resuscitation, especially in premature infants < 32 weeks GA; all neonates require continuous temperature monitoring during initial resuscitation, stabilization and transport. Target normal temperatures 36.5 to 37.5 ̊C
o Following initial steps of resuscitation, target preductal oxygen saturations 90 to 95%; In neonates with suspected congenital heart disease requiring Alprostadil infusion, review preductal oxygen saturation target with TMP
o In neonates with suspected persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn, target preductal oxygen saturations 92% to 95%</tab2>

pages.title: Paediatric - Bradycardia
pages.indications: Bradycardia
pages.contraindications: Allergy or sensitivity to the medication

dose_route: Initiate the appropriate algorithm based upon the presenting ECG rhythm

drug_cards.title: EPINEPHrine
dose_route:
0.01 mg/kg (0.1 mL/kg of 1:10,000 concentration) IV
Repeat q 3-5 min

drug_cards.title: EPINEPHrine
dose_route:
0.01 mg/kg (0.1 mL/kg of 1:10,000 concentration) IV
Repeat q 3-5 min
OR
0.1 microgram/kg/min IV infusion

drug_cards.title: Atropine
dose_route:
0.02 mg/kg IV/IO
MAX single dose: Child 0.5 mg; Adolescent 1 mg
May repeat dose once

pages.clinical:
<tab1>• Atropine Dose ETT if no IV/IO access: 0.04- 0.06 mg/kg/dose for symptomatic bradycardia
• Atropine for Toxins/overdose (i.e. organophosphate, carbamate)</tab1><tab2>
o < 12 years: 0.02- 0.05 mg/kg IV/IO initially; repeat q 20-30 minutes until symptoms are reversed
o > 12 years: 2 mg IV/IO initially; then 1-2 mg IV/IO q 20-30 minutes until symptoms are reversed</tab2>

pages.title: Paediatric - Tachycardia
pages.indications: <tab1>• Tachycardia</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>

dose_route: Initiate the appropriate algorithm based upon the presenting ECG rhythm

drug_cards.title: Adenosine
dose_route:
Adenosine 0.1 mg/kg rapid IV/IO bolus (MAX 6 mg)
followed by rapid Normal Saline flush 5-10 ml
Repeat Adenosine at 0.2 mg/kg q 2 min if no change

drug_cards.title: Procedural Sedation
dose_route: Ketamine 0.5 mg/kg OR Midazolam 0.05 mg/kg and/or FentaNYL 1 microgram/kg

pages.clinical: <tab1>• Adenosine should be administered in peripheral IV site close to patient's heat. Two syringes (one with Adenosine dose and one with NS flush) connected to a T-connector or stopcock is recommended for rapid administration of both medication and flush</tab1>

pages.title: Paediatric - Intravenous Line Initiation and Maintenance
pages.indications: <tab1>• Actual or potential need for intravenous drug or fluid therapy</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Suspected fracture proximal to the IV site</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Monitor
dose_route: Infants and children with an IV in place infusing at a rate of 5-15 mL/hr TKVO

Calculate IV rate of 80 mL/kg/day
Preferred solution D10W
Neonate (> 24 hours old) (< 28 days or 44 weeks corrected gestational age)

Calculate IV rate at 100 mL/kg/day
Preferred solution D10W & 0.2% Saline
(D5W & 0.9% NaCL) may be indicated in some circumstances

4 mL/hr x (0-10 kg)
+ 2 mL/hr x (10.1 kg-20 kg)
+ 1 mL/hr x (20.1 kg and greater)
D5W & 0.9% NaCL IV
0.9% normal saline may be indicated for maintenance when blood glucose levels are high

pages.clinical: <tab1>• Not applicable</tab1>

pages.title: Paediatric - Intraosseous Initiation and Maintenance
pages.indications:
<tab1>• Inadequate intravenous access for resuscitation
• Unable to obtain intravenous access after two (2) attempts or 90 seconds</tab1>
pages.contraindications:
<tab1>• Known or suspected fracture of affected limb
• Known or suspected injury, deformity, or infection overlying the proposed insertion site
• Absence of adequate anatomic landmarks</tab1>

dose_route: Initiate the appropriate intervention based upon the presenting condition

pages.clinical:
<tab1>• If the patient has hypovolemic shock, extensive burns, or major trauma but not in cardiac arrest or pre-arrest state, attempt to contact the TMP prior to using the IO device
• For neonates < 10 days of age and less than 3 kg, consider UVC Insertion
• Paediatric IOs can be placed in the proximal and distal tibia, distal femur and the humerus</tab1><tab2>
o Choosing the site is based on ability to landmark
o Issue with choosing the humerus is ability to landmark the greater tubercle in patients < 6 years old as this site is not yet well developed</tab2>

pages.title: Paediatric - Intraosseous Vascular Access Analgesia
pages.indications: <tab1>• Patient requiring intraosseous (IO) needle access and responsive to pain</tab1>
pages.contraindications:
<tab1>• Sino-atrial disorders
• All grades of AV block, Stokes-Adams syndrome, Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome
• Acute porphyria
• Hypersensitivity to another local anesthetic of the amide type</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Lidocaine 2% without epinephrine
drug_cards.notes: *Administer first dose over 2 minutes then allow lidocaine to dwell for 1 minute in IO space and flush with 5-10 ml 0.9% saline Followed by second dose of lidocaine over 1 minute

pages.clinical:
<tab1>• After the second lidocaine dose is given, medication or fluids may be administered under pressure as required
• Can consider administering again in 45 minutes later at the lower of the two previous doses given if discomfort re-occurs
• If extravasation occurs insert a new IO needle
• Cimetidine or beta-blockers (e.g. propranol) may interact and cause lidocaine toxicity</tab1>

pages.title: Paediatric - Umbilical Vein Catheterization
pages.indications:
<tab1>• No parenteral access is available in a newborn that requires IV therapy emergently (i.e. during neonatal resuscitation)
• When IV access cannot be obtained
• To treat hypoglycemia when IV dextrose concentration is greater than D12.5W</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Not applicable</tab1>

dose_route:
Recommended sizes for procedure are:
# 3.5 Fr for infants < 26+6 weeks gestation
# 5 Fr for infants > 27 weeks gestational age

pages.clinical:
<tab1>• Initiate the appropriate intervention based upon the presenting condition
• The umbilical vein is usually the most accessible vein in a newborn
• UVCs inserted with the catheter tip below the liver, and are considered ‘low lines’
• Do not substitute feeding tubes for Umbilical Venous Catheters</tab1>

pages.title: Paediatric - Venous/Capillary Blood Sampling and Lab Value Interpretation
pages.indications:
<tab1>• To establish baseline respiratory, cardiovascular, hematological status prior to or during transport
• To monitor changes and/or deterioration in clinical status</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Not applicable</tab1>

dose_route: Perform venipuncture, venous/capillary blood sampling and utilize iSTAT if available

pages.clinical:
<tab1>• Management based on these results will be via patch with the Paediatric TMP
• These tests should only be completed if absolutely essential to patient management en route and will not cause unnecessary delays in initiating transport</tab1>

pages.title: Paediatric - Arterial Blood Sampling Auxiliary Medical Directive
pages.indications:
<tab1>• To establish baseline respiratory, cardiovascular, hematological status prior to or during transport
• To monitor changes and/or deterioration in clinical status</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Not applicable</tab1>

dose_route: Perform arterial puncture to obtain blood for diagnostic or monitoring purposes

pages.clinical:
<tab1>• The need for further clinical management based on blood sample results will be discussed during patch with the Paediatric TMP
• These tests should only be completed if absolutely essential to patient management en route and will not cause unnecessary delays in initiating transport</tab1>

pages.title: Paediatric - Central Venous and Arterial Line Monitoring
pages.indications: <tab1>• Established arterial and venous line</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• PCP(f)s may not access, maintain or monitor a central venous access device (CVAD)</tab1>

dose_route: Monitor an established central venous line using the following heparin concentrations: 2 units/mL added to Normal Saline for all infants and children 1 unit/mL added to Normal Saline for all neonates (under 28 days)

pages.clinical:
<tab1>• All paediatric central lines require heparinized fluids to maintain patency
• All paediatric arterial lines require heparinized fluids to maintain patency
• This directive does not permit access to venous devices that are located subcutaneously, such as a PortaCath or similar
• Arterial lines are calibrated (zeroed) with any changes in level of bed &/or position of head of bed to transducer, if waveform changes and with IV tubing changes
• Ensure all connections are tight , line is secured (i.e. arm board) and limb properly restrained as required
• Blood backing up the transducer tubing from the patient may indicate a leak, crack or loose connections</tab1>

pages.title: Paediatric - Seizures
pages.indications: Active seizure
pages.contraindications:
• If blood glucose < 3 mmol/L, proceed with “Hypoglycemic Emergencies”. Concurrently, medicate with a benzodiazepine (as stated below) for treatment of seizure
• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication

drug_cards.title: Midazolam (Versed)
dose_route:
Midazolam infusion: initiate at 50 microgram/kg/hour q 5 min to a MAX of 1400 microgram/kg/hour
Bolus with 0.15 mg/kg/dose to MAX of 4 mg/dose IV/IO prior to each titration

drug_cards.title: LORazepam (Ativan)
dose_route:
0.1 mg/kg IV/IO
To a MAX of 4 mg
May repeat q 5 minutes
To a MAX of 8 mg

drug_cards.title: Fosphenytoin
dose_route:
20 mg PE*/kg IV/IM Infuse over 5 to 10 mins
MAX dose 3 mL/site IM
If > 30 kg, requires multiple sites
drug_cards.notes: *PE (phenyTOIN equivalents)

drug_cards.title: phenyTOIN (Dilantin)
dose_route: 20 mg mg/kg IV/IM Infuse over 20 mins Note: USE NORMAL SALINE ONLY as phenyTOIN will precipitate in dextrose solutions

pages.clinical: • If the seizure is not terminated within five 5 minutes of administration of Midazolam, AND the ACP(f), CCP and the PCCP/PCCN is unable to establish contact with the TMP, a repeat dose of Midazolam (0.1 mg/kg IV) may be administered • Fosphenytoin is the preferred drug over phenyTOIN due to its’ enhanced safety profile, should be given in preference if available • Following benzodiazepine administration in the seizure algorithm, Fosphenytoin and/or phenyTOIN are the preferred seizure medications in Paediatrics > 1 month • 0.2 micron filter must be used when administering phenyTOIN • No micron filter is required to administer Fosphenytoin • Fosphenytoin/ phenyTOIN should not be used with a diagnosis of toxic ingestion or in the setting of a cardiac conduction system disturbance • Consider reducing the rate of phenyTOIN administration to 25 mg/min in children with cardiac conditions

pages.title: Paediatric - Traumatic Cardiac Arrest
pages.indications: <tab1>• Cardiac arrest due to trauma</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Vital signs present</tab1>

drug_cards.title: 0.9% Normal Saline
dose_route:
20 mL/kg IV bolus
MAX 1 L
Target SBP 70 + (2x age)
Initiate the appropriate algorithm based upon the presenting ECG rhythm

pages.clinical:
<tab1>• PCP(f) may apply the Medical Directives for the management of cardiac arrest with semi-automated defibrillation
• TMP patch prior to initiating transport of patient in cardiac arrest for consideration of TOR</tab1>

pages.title: Paediatric - Severe Traumatic Brain Injury (GCS < 8, Abnormal CT)

dose_route: Initiate the appropriate algorithm based upon the flowchart

pages.title: Paediatric - Volume Replacement in Non Hemorrhagic Hypovolemic Hypotension
pages.indications:
<tab1>• Acute paediatric hypovolemia
• Children exhibiting manifestations of cardiovascular compromise: delayed capillary refill time (> 3 seconds), poor peripheral pulses, pale and/or mottling, cool extremities, tachycardia
• Hypotensive children
• Children in cardiopulmonary arrest</tab1>
pages.contraindications:
<tab1>• Known hypersensitivity, adverse side effects or newly presenting side effects
• Parents refuse treatment/blood product-consult with TMP
• Blood products when parents are known Jehovah Witness-consult with TMP</tab1>
pages.clinical:
<tab1>• *In hypotensive DKA patients fluid boluses should be more conservative (Normal Saline 10 mL/kg IV over 1 hr)
• Ringers Lactate should not be used in DKA patients
• In children with known cardiovascular compromise, only give Normal Saline 5-10 mL/kg IV bolus
• Reassess patient response to fluid bolus (i.e. Assess for decrease in heart rate, improved capillary refill time, improved pulses and urine output)
• Severe hypovolemia from blood loss should prompt consideration for the early use of blood products. In cases requiring massive transfusion include both packed red blood cells and fresh frozen plasma</tab1>

drug_cards.title:
May administer an IV crystalloid bolus of 20 mL/kg (may repeat x 1).
The patient must be carefully observed for any signs of fluid overload.
Assessments re: volume status (i.e. vital signs, chest auscultation findings) should be documented frequently
dose_route: *Give rapidly for hypotension, poor perfusion - may repeat up to a MAX of 40 mL/kg IV before contact with TMP

drug_cards.title: Initiate or maintain the administration of blood and/or blood products as per Ornge Policy
dose_route: Give over 30 min for known coagulopathy or evidence of DIC
May repeat up to a MAX of 40 mL/kg IV/IO

pages.title: Paediatric - Cardiovascular Support
pages.indications: <tab1>• Exhibiting manifestations of cardiovascular compromise, delayed capillary refill (> 3 seconds), poor peripheral pulses, mottling/pale, cool extremities</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>
pages.clinical:
<tab1>• Patient must be on a cardio-respiratory monitor, with frequent blood pressure monitoring
• Titrate infusions to keep Systolic BP > 70 + (age x 2) or Systolic BP as per Paediatric TMP order
• Refer to Medication Information section for Medication Infusion Rate Charts</tab1>

pages.title: Paediatric - Push Dose Epinephrine – 10 mcg/ml (1:100 000)
pages.indications: <tab1>• Restoration of circulation temporarily, during paediatric PERI-ARREST and shock states presenting with severe hypotension and/or bradycardia for ages</tab1>
pages.contraindications:
<tab1>• Patients receiving chest compressions
• Patients in cardiac arrest</tab1>
pages.clinical: • During CARDIAC ARREST only a dose 10 mcg/kg of Epinephrine 1: 10 000 (100 mcg/ml) Pre-loaded syringe (1 mg/10 ml) should be used • Types of critically ill patients in whom Epinephrine 1: 100 000 may be considered include: o Acute Hypotension in severe shock states o Heart Disease (e.g. unstable coronary perfusion, cardiomyopathy, heart failure, myocarditis) Prior to intubation in patients with shock o Patients on Epinephrine infusions >0.5 mcg/kg/min • Epinephrine 1: 100 000 allows for restoration of circulation temporarily and avoids tachycardia and vasoconstriction that can occur with CARDIAC ARREST doses (10 mcg/kg) • Epinephrine 1: 100 000 may provide temporary stabilization while other therapies are added or adjusted/titrated • Delivered as a concentration of Epinephrine 1: 100 000 ( 10 micrograms/ml) which is equal to a dose volume of 0.1 ml/kg/dose Preparation of Epinephrine 1: 100 000 1. Using a 10 ml syringe, draw 100 microgram (i.e. 1 ml of 1: 10 000) EPINEPHrine and dilute in 9 ml of Normal Saline.

drug_cards.title: EPINEPHrine 10 mcg/ml (1: 100 000)
dose_route:
1 mcg/kg/dose (0.1 ml/kg/dose) IV/IO
May repeat q 5 minutes
Target SBP > 70 + (2x age in years)

pages.title: Paediatric - Septic Shock
pages.indications:
<tab1>• Cardiovascular dysfunction (hypotension [SBP < 70 + (2x age)], prolonged capillary refill, oliguria, metabolic acidosis, elevated arterial lactate)
• Hemodynamic abnormalities persist despite > 40 mL/kg of fluid in one hour
• GCS < 11</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>
pages.clinical: • Paediatrics are seldom in a pure warm shock state; Norepinephrine is rarely used as first line agent • Norepinephrine is for patients who are CLEARLY in warm shock state (wide pulse pressure, warm extremities, bounding pulses, brisk CRT) • Children are often significantly hypovolemic (from not keeping up with insensibles & 3rd spacing; especially infants who don't control their intake), therefore have a component of cold (vasoconstricted shock), myocardial dysfunction (occurs earlier in sepsis in paediatrics) and therefore an element of cardiogenic shock (cold shock) • Prepare 2nd line inotropes early • Monitor peripheral infusions of Epinephrine & Norepinephrine > 0.05 mcg/kg/min closely for signs of extravasation. In profound hypotension, infusions may be titrated > 0.1 mcg/kg/min, but this is not optimal in peripheral IV sites and should be discussed with Paediatric TMP • Physiologic indicators and target goals: strong distal pulses equal to central pulses, warm peripheries with CRT < 2 seconds, improved GCS (normal mental status), urine output > 1 ml/kg/hr, BP although not in itself a reliable endpoint for resuscitation, systolic BP 60 mmHg in infants , 1 month old; 70 mmHg + (2 x age in years) in children 1 month to 10 years of age; 90mm Hg in children 10 years of age or older • Vancomycin can be added by TMP based on severity of infection and risk factors in catchment area. Vancomycin should not be given without a patch

drug_cards.title: Isotonic Crystalloid or Colloid
dose_route:
20 mL/kg bolus IV/IO within 20 min
(MAX 60 mL/kg)
Target SBP >70 + (2 x age)

drug_cards.title: DOPamine (Intropin)
dose_route:
5-10 microgram/kg/min IV/IO
Target SBP >70 + (2 x age)

drug_cards.title: EPINEPHrine (Adrenalin)
dose_route:
0.05-0.3 microgram/kg/min IV/IO
Target SBP >70 + (2 x age)

drug_cards.title: Hydrocortisone
drug_cards.notes: Consider pericardial effusion, pneumothorax and increased intraabdominal pressure for persistent catecholamine resistant shock

pages.title: Paediatric - Nausea, Vomiting and Motion Sickness
pages.indications: • The patient is <40 kg • The patient is suffering from nausea or vomiting • There is an increased risk of motion sickness in transport • The patient has not received dimenhyDRINATE within the last 4 hours
pages.contraindications:
<tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication
• Prolonged QT (concern in Ondansetron administration or concomitant use of other drugs that may prolong the QT interval)
• The patient has received Ondansetron within 8 hours
• The patient has received dimenhyDRINATE within the last 4 hours</tab1>
pages.clinical: <tab1>• Not applicable</tab1>

drug_cards.title: dimenhyDRINATE (Gravol)
dose_route:
1 mg/kg IM/PO
To a MAX of 40 mg

drug_cards.section: Ondansetron is considered the first line agent for nausea and vomiting
drug_cards.title: Ondansetron (Zofran)
dose_route:
Oral dose > 6 months
0.15 mg/kg/dose PO x 1 dose
8-15 kg: 2 mg
15-30 kg: 4 mg
>30 kg: 8 mg

drug_cards.title: dimenhyDRINATE (Gravol)
dose_route: Give SLOW IV push to prevent vertigo, weakness and dizziness

pages.title: Paediatric - Gastric (NG or OG) Tubes
pages.indications:
<tab1>• Actual or anticipated need to evacuate gastric contents in bowel obstructions
• Intubated and ventilated patients</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Patients presenting with facial fracture or suspected basal skull fracture should not have a nasogastric tube inserted</tab1>
pages.clinical: <tab1>• A nasal or oral gastric tube should be placed prior to transport whenever possible with unresponsive paediatric patients</tab1>

dose_route: Insertion and/or Maintenance Ensure the gastric tube is appropriately located via auscultation Confirm by partner prior to departure

pages.title: Paediatric - Esophageal Temperature Probes
pages.indications:
<tab1>• Continuous monitoring of core body temperature for any intubated patient with a temperature outside normal range (36 to 37˚C)
• Temperature monitoring during active rewarming measures
• Continuous monitoring may be ordered by the TMP at their discretion</tab1>
pages.contraindications:
<tab1>• Esophageal strictures
• Esophageal varices
• Esophageal perforation
• Congenital anomalies such as tracheal esophageal fistula
• Post-operative tonsillectomy and adenoidectomy patients
• Facial trauma
• Coagulopathies (review history with Paediatric TMP)
• Patients receiving Anticoagulants. Anticoagulants include but are not limited to: unfractionated heparin IV bolus or infusion, Warfarin (Coumadin), Enoxaparin (Lovenox), or NOACs/DOACs</tab1>
pages.clinical: <tab1>• It is preferable to assess position of probe using a CXR (should not delay initiating transport)</tab1>

dose_route: Insert and monitor core temperature with Esophageal Temperature probe

pages.title: Paediatric - Urinary Catheter Insertion and Maintenance
pages.indications:
<tab1>• For monitoring urine output
• For urinary tract obstruction</tab1>
pages.contraindications:
<tab1>• Suspected pelvic fracture or urethral tear
• Patient < 28 days or 44 weeks corrected</tab1>
pages.clinical:
<tab1>• Urinary catheter removal can only be performed by the ACP(f), CCP and PCCP/PCCN
• Contact the TMP if the catheter becomes obstructed during transport</tab1>

dose_route: Contact the TMP if the catheter becomes obstructed during transport

pages.title: Paediatric - Fever
pages.indications: <tab1>• Temperature exceeding 38oC via the axilla route and 38.5oC via the tympanic, oral, or rectal route</tab1>
pages.contraindications:
<tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication
• Acetaminophen within the last 4 hours
• Ibuprofen:</tab1><tab2>
o NSAID or Ibuprofen use within previous 6 hours
o Patient on anticoagulation therapy
o Current active bleeding
o Hx of peptic ulcer disease or GI bleed
o Pregnant
o If asthmatic, no prior use of ASA or other NSAIDs
o CVA or TBI in the previous 24 hours
o Known renal impairment
o Active vomiting
o Unable to tolerate oral medication</tab2>

drug_cards.title: Acetaminophen (Tylenol)
dose_route:
<center>15 mg/kg every 4 hours PO or PR
MAX 1 gram
(Suspension or Suppository)</center>

pages.clinical:
<tab1>• Suppositories available in 120 mg, 325 mg and 650 mg
• Rectal temperatures are preferred for children < 2 years of age, axillary or oral temperatures ≥ 2 years of age</tab1>

pages.title: Paediatric - Anaphylaxis
pages.indications:
<tab1>• Confirmed or suspected history of exposure to an allergen
AND
• Moderate to severe allergic reaction including anaphylaxis</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>

drug_cards.title: EPINEPHrine (Adrenalin) (1:1000 Solution)
dose_route:
IM EPINEPHrine dose:
0.01 mg/kg
(min 0.1 mg/dose to MAX 0.4 mg/dose)
May repeat x 1 after 5 minutes if symptoms persist

drug_cards.title: Crystalloids
dose_route:
20 mL/kg IV/IO bolus if signs of hemodynamic instability
MAX 1 Litre
Target SBP 70 + 2x age

drug_cards.title: Salbutamol (Ventolin) Solution Via Nebulized Aerosol (2.5 mg/2.5 mL)
dose_route:
2.5 mg* (1.0 mL)
Repeat q 30 minutes - 4 hours prn

5 mg* (2.0 mL)
Repeat q 30 minutes - 4 hours prn
drug_cards.notes: * Dilute salbutamol dose to 3 mL in normal saline; dose limit of added saline: MAX 1 mL/dose

drug_cards.title: Salbutamol (Ventolin) via MDI 100 microgram / puff
dose_route: 4 puffs (400 microgram) q 15-20 min x 3 doses
8 puffs (800 microgram) q 15-20 min x 3 doses

drug_cards.title: diphenhyDRAMINE (Benadryl)
dose_route:
1 mg/kg/dose
To a MAX of 40 mg/dose

drug_cards.title: EPINEPHrine (Adrenalin)
dose_route:
0.05-0.3 microgram/kg/min IV/IO
Target BP (70 + (2 x age))

pages.clinical: • Re-assess frequently during transport • After patch with Paediatric TMP, treatment may include administration of corticosteroids such as o Dexamethasone 0.3 mg/kg/dose IV/IM once daily (MAX 12 mg/dose), OR o Hydrocortisone 5-10 mg/kg/dose IV q 6 hours (MAX 100 mg/dose), OR o methylPREDNISolone 1 mg/kg dose IV q 8 hours (MAX 60 mg/dose) • If signs of hemodynamic instability, consider normal saline 20 mL/kg bolus IV for hypotension • EPINEPHrine administration must not exceed one dose prior to patch. Patch for further management • Patient may require EPINEPHrine infusion 0.1-1 microgram/kg/min in severe exacerbations

pages.title: Paediatric - Hypoglycemia
pages.indications:
<tab1>• Blood glucose < 3 mmol/L
AND any one of the following:</tab1><tab2>
o Altered level of consciousness (GCS <14)
OR
o Confirmed history of diabetes mellitus
OR
o Active seizures within the past one hour</tab2>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>
pages.clinical:
<tab1>• Glucagon infusions may be used for persistent hypoglycemia in neonates or children
• Contraindications to Glucagon</tab1><tab2>
o Pheochromocytoma: tumor of the adrenal medulla or sympathetic paraganglia, characterized by hypersecretion of EPINEPHrine and Norepinephrine</tab2>

drug_cards.title: Glucagon
dose_route:
0.1 mg/kg IM
to a MAX 0.5 mg/dose
Repeat blood glucose measurement 20 minutes after the administration of Glucagon Follow with oral carbohydrates ASAP if LOC permits (i.e. juice, snack)
Repeat blood glucose measurement 20 minutes after the administration of Glucagon Follow with oral carbohydrates ASAP if LOC permits (i.e. juice, snack)

(5 mL/kg of D10W)

0.5 gm/kg of D25W
(2 mL/kg of D25W)

0.5 gm/kg of D50W
(1 mL/kg of D50W)
To a MAX of 25 gm (50 mL)

dose_route: 25 mL of 1 prefilled syringe of D50W

drug_cards.title: Glucagon Infusion
dose_route:
1.0 mg (1 mg/mL) in 23 mL D5W or D10W and infuse at 
1 mL/hr for 24 hours (up to a MAX 2 mg in 24 mL solution over 24 hours)

pages.title: Neonatal - Hypoglycemia
pages.indications:
<tab1>• Blood glucose < 3 mmol/L
• Jitteriness or tremors
• Episodes of cyanosis
• Apneic spells
• High pitched cry
• Altered level of consciousness (limpless or lethargy)
• Seizures</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>
pages.clinical:
<tab1>• Risk Factors for Hypoglycemia:</tab1><tab2>
o Prematurity (< 37 wks GA), SGA, IUGR, LGA, IDM</tab2>

dose_route:
<center>0.2 gm/kg of D10W
(2 mL/kg of D10W)</center>

Increase maintenance glucose concentration to D12.5W
Repeat blood glucose 15 minutes after interventions
If hypoglycemia persists increase maintenance glucose concentration to D15W.
IV D15W can only be administered in a central line (umbilical venous catheter, PICC line)

dose_route: 25 mL of 1 prefilled syringe of D50W

dose_route: 20 mL of 1 prefilled syringe of D50W

dose_route: 25 mL of 1 prefilled syringe of D50W
Syringe Preparation: Add 15 mL of D50W to 35 mL of NS to create total volume of 50 mL of D15W

drug_cards.title: Hypoglycemia
dose_route: 2 mL/kg bolus of D10W increase IV fluids to D12.5W or D15W

Reassess blood glucose
q 15 minutes after interventions until > 3.0 mmol/L

drug_cards.title: Normoglycemia
dose_route:
IV D10W
(80 mL/kg/day)
Equivalent to glucose infusion rate of 5 mg/kg/min
Communicate blood glucose results to TMP
Continue to monitor blood glucose as directed by TMP
Reassess blood glucose following changes in GIR or q 3 hrs if blood glucose remains normal

drug_cards.title: Hyperglycemia
dose_route: Communicate blood glucose results to TMP
Continue to monitor blood glucose as directed by TMP

pages.title: Paediatric - Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA)
pages.indications:
<tab1>• Hyperglycemia (blood glucose > 11 mmol/L) in a new or known diabetic
AND
• pH <7.30 and serum bicarbonate <15 mmol/L
AND (if available)
• Confirmed ketosis (positive ketones in blood or urine)</tab1>
<title>Monitoring</title>
<tab1>• Cardiorespiratory monitor and O2 saturation monitor
• Monitoring of vital signs (HR, RR, BP) and neurovitals, q 10-15 minutes
• Accurate intake and output q 1 hour
• Bedside glucose q 1 hour</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>
pages.clinical: <tab1>• All Paediatric patients < 18 years of age should be managed using the paediatric DKA algorithm</tab1>

drug_cards.title: 0.9% Normal Saline MAX 250 mL/hr
drug_cards.notes: * Add 40 mEq/L KCl to 0.9 % infusion if serum K+ < 5.5 mmol/L and patient is passing urine

pages.title: Paediatric - Suspected Opioid Overdose
pages.indications:
<tab1>• GCS of < 12 or altered level of consciousness
AND
• Respiratory rate < 10
AND
• Suspected acute opioid overdose</tab1>
pages.contraindications:
<tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication
• If Blood glucose < 3 mmol/L, proceed with “Hypoglycemic Emergencies”</tab1>
pages.clinical: <tab1>• Management of airway, breathing and circulation remain the first priority: adequate oxygenation and ventilation must be ensured</tab1>

drug_cards.title: Naloxone (Narcan)
dose_route:
0.1 mg/kg IM every 2 minutes prn
(up to a MAX total of 0.1 mg/kg or 2 mg)

drug_cards.title: Naloxone (Narcan)
dose_route:
0.1 mg/kg
IV, IM, IO or ETT every 2 minutes prn
(up to a MAX total of 0.1 mg/kg or 2 mg) (IV/IO route, followed by IM route are preferred)

pages.title: Paediatric - Suspected Acetaminophen Toxicity
pages.indications: <tab1>• Suspected acetaminophen toxicity</tab1>
pages.contraindications: <tab1>• Allergy or sensitivity to the medication</tab1>
pages.clinical: • Mandatory Patch required to initiate an acetylcysteine infusion • The ACP(f), CCP and PCCP/PCCN may maintain the administration of a MucomystTM (acetylcysteine) infusion for an acetaminophen overdose in the following circumstances: o The infusion was initiated by the sending facility o Ingested or suspected ingestion of acetaminophen dose is greater or equal to: • 7.5 gm OR • 150 mg/kg o The rate of infusion is in accordance with the accompanying dosage table and preparation guide o The rate of infusion cannot be altered by the Paramedic unless ordered by the Transport Medicine Physician Guidelines to Prepare a 3% Intravenous N-Acetylcysteine Bag As part of the Poison Centre’s treatment recommendations for the acetaminophen-poisoned patient, a 3 % n-acetylcysteine solution will need to be prepared. The following are instructions on how to prepare this solution in D5W. Patient is <20 kg: • Remove 37.5 ml from a 250 ml bag of D5W • Add 37.5 ml of 20% IV N-Acetylcysteine to the remaining 212.5 ml in the D5W bag o 37.5 ml X 200mg/ml = 7 500 mg of N-Acetylcysteine o 7500 mg in 250 ml yields a final solution with 30 mg/ml or 3% Notes: 1. 20% IV N-Acetylcysteine is equivalent to 200 mg/mL 2. The 3% solution is slightly hyperosmolar but still within the safety margin for administration via a peripheral vein 3. It is recognized that any particular bag of IV fluid could have excessive fluid more than advertised. It is of little consequence when making this 3% solution. Assume a finished volume as advertised on the bag Mixing is important to ensure uniform distribution of N-Acetylcysteine in infusion solution.

drug_cards.title: Maintenance Infusion: 3% Mucomyst (Acetylcysteine) Dosage Guide and Preparation for IV Administration (reference CPS)

pages.title: Guideline for Paediatric Vital Signs/Tube Sizes
content: Initial endotracheal tube insertion depth ('tip to lip') for orotracheal intubation
Adapted from Kempley ST, Moreira JW, Petrone FL. Endotracheal tube length for neonatal intubation. Resuscitation. 2008;77(3):369-373

<tab1>• Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP) is variable based on patient age and cuff size, systolic blood pressure is less impacted by this, therefore thresholds for blood pressure interventions or precautions are based on systolic pressure in the < 12 years or < 40 kg paediatric population
• Blood pressures listed in the table above are within the 50 percentile for age/weight
• BroselowTM/paediatric tape version acceptable
• ETT size formula: one year of age or more:</tab1><tab2>
o Uncuffed = (Age in years)/4) + 4 = tube size in mm
o Cuffed=(Age in years)/4) + 3.5 = tube size in mm
o Cuffed ETT’s can be used in any pediatric patient except newborns</tab2>
